Curiosity has peaked leading up to the big launch, leaving fans excited about potential future developments. The post-credits scene, a staple of Marvel movies, has always provided hints and teases for what's next in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.\n\nFor those wondering about the Deadpool & Wolverine end-credits scene and its implications, here is everything you need to know.\n\nWhat happens in the final Deadpool & Wolverine post-credits scene?\n\nPrior to the post-credits scene, a montage featuring behind-the-scenes clips from previous Fox Marvel movies plays. Then, after the credits, a scene plays out linking back to an earlier gag in the movie.\n\nFox Marvel behind-the-scenes montage\n\nDuring the credits of Deadpool & Wolverine, a heartfelt montage set to the \"Good Riddance\" song by Green Day plays. It showcases behind-the-scenes clips from various X-Men movies, ranging from The Last Stand to Dark Phoenix.\n\nIt includes Ryan Reynolds discussing his desire to play Deadpool, Jennifer Garner suiting up as Elektra, and several other lighthearted moments with the cast. This highlights iconic Fox characters and actors, celebrating the X-Men franchise's legacy while acknowledging its transition into the MCU.\n\nJohnny Storm's post-credits scene\n\nThe post-credits scene in Deadpool & Wolverine takes an unexpected turn. Instead of hinting at future Marvel movies, it humorously resolves an earlier plot point. Throughout the movie, Deadpool claims that Johnny Storm (Chris Evans) made terrible comments about Cassandra Nova, leading to Johnny's death.\n\nThese crude remarks seemed out of character for Chris Evans, who previously played Captain America and is famous for his \"language!\" line. This made viewers suspect Deadpool fabricated the comments to save himself.\n\nIn the post-credits scene, Deadpool returns to the TVA to clear his name. He presents a tape showing a conversation between Johnny Storm, Deadpool, and Wolverine, all tied up in a prisoner transport pod on their way to Cassandra Nova. The recording reveals Johnny Storm actually saying every horrible thing Deadpool claimed, delivering each insult with unsettling naturalness.\n\nThis revelation provides a laugh-out-loud moment, {"uri": "2024-07-433363727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:38:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:38:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:37:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.comingsoon.net/guides/news/1812707-lady-deadpool-voice-actor-mask-look-like-3-wolverine", "title": "Deadpool & Wolverine: Who Voices Lady Deadpool? What Does She Look Like Unmasked?", "body": "Many fans are eager to know who voices Lady Deadpool in Deadpool & Wolverine and what she looks like unmasked. The question of Lady Deadpool's voice has been particularly intriguing, with speculation around whether Ryan Reynolds' wife, Blake Lively, is behind the character. Curiosity also surrounds her appearance without the mask, as her comic book counterpart originally shared many features with Deadpool, including cancer scars.\n\nFor details on Lady Deadpool's voice, unmasked appearance, and Blake Lively's rumored role, here's what you need to know.\n\nDoes Blake Lively voice Lady Deadpool in Deadpool & Wolverine?\n\nYes, Blake Lively voices Lady Deadpool in Deadpool & Wolverine.\n\nLady Deadpool appears prominently in the movie's final act as part of the Deadpool Corps. She is joined by other variants like Babypool, Headpool, Cowboy Deadpool (played by Matthew McConaughey), and Kidpool (played by Inez Reynolds). The Deadpool Corps, sent by Cassandra Nova, distracts Deadpool and Wolverine. This diversion is part of her plan to use the Time Ripper to destroy all timelines.\n\nLively's participation adds a playful and meta element to the film, especially given her marriage to Ryan Reynolds, who plays Deadpool. She even fueled speculation by attending the world premiere in a Deadpool-esque red catsuit, teasing her role.\n\nWhat does Blake Lively's Lady Deadpool look like under the mask?\n\nIn Deadpool & Wolverine, Blake Lively voices Lady Deadpool, who stays masked throughout the film. As a result, the film does not reveal her appearance under the mask. However, it's assumed that she looks like Blake Lively.\n\nIn the comics, Lady Deadpool is initially portrayed as a female version of Deadpool, sharing features like cancer scars. However, her appearance evolves over time. Recent depictions show her free from scars and with perfect blonde hair, unlike Wade Wilson, who is often bald.\n\nThe decision to keep Lady Deadpool masked in the movie aligns with her comic book portrayal, where her identity remains ambiguous. This approach preserves the mystery and continuity of her character, while Blake Lively's voice adds depth to the role.", "source": {"uri": "comingsoon.net", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8243829483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-26", "time": "00:01:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-26T00:01:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-26T00:00:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.lowyinstitute.org/the-interpreter/deadpool-wolverine-can-rescue-america-trump", "title": "Deadpool & Wolverine can rescue America from Trump", "body": "Already the talk is that the latest Deadpool instalment can save the ailing Marvel cinematic universe. It has certainly been a while since I've walked away smiling from a superhero film. But if Batman from The Dark Knight in 2008 could be adopted by conservatives in an election year as a masked metaphor in support of George W Bush and the \"war on terror\", Deadpool & Wolverine in 2024 stands as an antidote to the misery of Trumpism.\n\nStick with me. This is a mad ride and carries a spoiler.\n\nLike politics, the storytelling in Marvel movies has broken in recent years - literally splintered into a gazillion bizarre threads of a \"multiverse\".\n\nIn some of these many worlds, red means go, up means down. Logic is impossible. Any character can be killed off, only to be plucked from another timeline to make a triumphant return. Alternative facts are the rule.\n\nIn this film, Deadpool pokes fun at this post-truth world. He winks knowingly at previous flops in which Marvel has over-reached. It's pop culture, not politics, with a coarse humour that exposes absurdity.\n\nWhereas the superhero movies of 2016 delivered an emphasis on relationship breakdowns, the title and theme of this movie, Deadpool AND Wolverine, imply finding a way together.\n\nWolverine is himself a resurrected hero. In one world he is dead, as he was left in 2017's Logan, with the inspiring legacy of ultimate self sacrifice. In this movie, Deadpool literally digs up Wolverine's skeletal remains to beat his enemies. Talk about an image to portray the modern abuses of history.\n\nThen Wolverine is brought back to life, drawn from a parallel universe. This version of Wolverine went missing at a time of dire need. He sees the chance to undo the mistakes of the past, to wave a magic wand of redemption. Only suffering and bitter experience, he is reminded at the end, give him the strength of character to do what is needed.\n\nI saw a story of politics. That easy fixes are not the answer and testing times have a value in and of themselves. Of course I'm projecting. Deadpool is not Donald any more than Wolverine is Kamala. But together the arc of these characters struck me as a collective experience of the past few years.\n\nDeadpool is the ultimate gaslighter; his lies have deadly consequences. Wolverine is a grumpy nostalgic who regards Deadpool as the worst person he's met in more than 200 years. They fight. They punch and stab and shoot one another in the most absurd ways. But their superpower is that neither can die. They are stuck together. Only by cooperating can they win.\n\nWhereas the superhero movies of 2016 delivered Captain America: Civil War and Batman v Superman, with an emphasis on relationship breakdowns (note the year of release, when Trump prevailed over Hillary Clinton), the title and theme of this movie, Deadpool AND Wolverine, imply finding a way together.\n\nThe film is interspersed with cameo appearances and feel-good moments that serve as a reminder of happier times, not as answers to suggest the ultimate dominance of one side over the other. They are more a sentimental fix to the universe, harking back to a time when people laughed more along with the ride.", "source": {"uri": "lowyinstitute.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lowy Institute for International Policy"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadpool_(video_game)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Deadpool (video game)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolverine", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Wolverine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Comics", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Marvel Comics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superhero_film", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Superhero film"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_on_terror", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "War on terror"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiverse", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Multiverse"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared_universe", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Shared universe"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batman_in_film", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Batman in film"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batman_(TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Batman (TV series)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphor", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Metaphor"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_W._Bush", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "George W. {"uri": "8243792904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:11:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:11:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:10:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.inverse.com/entertainment/deadpool-wolverine-chris-evans-cameo-human-torch-fantastic-four", "title": "'Deadpool & Wolverine's Biggest Cameo Redeems a Failed Superhero Movie Crossover", "body": "Deadpool and Wolverine made it very clear that no matter how many cameos it teased in its trailers, there were even more in store in the full movie. We may have seen Cassandra Nova, Sabretooth, and X-23 already, but the Void contained so much more for Marvel fans, from the obscure to the obvious, and everything in between.\n\nBut one of the biggest cameos in the movie was exciting not because of who appeared, but because of who didn't appear -- and it could be teasing an even bigger cameo in the future.\n\nWarning! Spoilers for Deadpool & Wolverine ahead!\n\nWhen Deadpool and Wolverine are fighting each other in the Void from Loki Season 1, a third party suddenly enters to mediate. \"You fight each other in the Wasteland, we all lose,\" he says. At first, it's difficult to see who this figure is, but as a posse of bad guys roll up on apocalyptic cars, he jumps down and we get a better look.\n\nDeadpool is excited, and for good reason: when this figure lowers his hood, he's none other than Chris Evans, the man who saved the world during the Time Heist and wielded Thor's Hammer. Or rather, it's the actor who did all that. Despite Deadpool's excitement, this isn't the return of Steve Rogers that fans have been demanding. He may be wearing a blue and white suit, but when he gets ready to say his catchphrase, he says \"Flame on,\" igniting and shooting off into the sky.\n\nThat's right -- Chris Evans isn't reprising the role of Steve Rogers, but Johnny Storm from the 2005 movie Fantastic Four, one of the Fox-era pre-MCU Marvel movies Deadpool & Wolverine pays constant homage to.\n\nThis isn't a huge surprise if you've been keeping up with Chris Evans' post-Marvel career. He's collaborated with Ryan Reynolds and director Shawn Levy before in Free Guy, and the choice to reprise Johnny Storm is actually something he's considered before. In 2022, MTV asked if he'd ever go back to that role again, and said it would actually be an \"easier sell\" than returning as Cap. \"Cap is so precious to me. And you know, I almost don't wanna disrupt what a beautiful experience that was,\" he said. \"But Johnny Storm, I feel like he didn't really get his day. That was before Marvel really found its footing.\"\n\nJohnny Storm's cameo is also an homage to the X-Men and Fantastic Four crossover that never happened. For years, 20th Century Fox had planned to crossover its X-Men franchise with the Fantastic Four, with a movie being penned by Zack Stenz and Ashley Edward Miller, that would've also featured Deadpool and Daredevil. Alas, the crossover movie never came to be. But at least we have Deadpool & Wolverine to make up for it.\n\nThe cameo also doesn't undo Steve Rogers' touching sendoff in Avengers: Endgame -- nor does it completely erase the possibility of Cap coming back even after his mantle has been passed down to Sam Wilson. In an interview with DiscussingFilm, Marvel president Kevin Feige said Deadpool and Wolverine actually may have proven those kinds of cameos are still possible. \"I think Hugh's appearance and starring role in [Deadpool & Wolverine] is a great sign that it can be done -- if great care is taken,\" he said.\n\nSo America's ass may be back on the big screen, it's just on fire this time. Wilson busts out some moves to NSYNC's \"Bye Bye Bye\" while using the bones to brutally hack, slash and dismember his foes.\n\nAt one point, he even sticks his own hands through Wolvie's forearms and pops his claws.\n\nIf this all sounds very disrespectful, well, that's kinda the point - but it also happens to be one of the funniest moments in a consistently hilarious movie.\n\nIf you've been to see the movie, what did you make of this scene? Did you find it off-putting, or did you see the funny side? Let us know in the comments section.\n\nDeadpool and Wolverine currently sits at 80% on Rotten Tomatoes with 153 reviews counted.\n\nThe MPAA recently gave the movie an official R-rating for: \"Strong bloody violence and language throughout, gore, and sexual references.\"\n\n\"Marvel Studios presents their most significant mistake to date - Deadpool & Wolverine,\" reads the new synopsis. \"A listless Wade Wilson toils away in civilian life. His days as the morally flexible mercenary, Deadpool, behind him. When his homeworld faces an existential threat, Wade must reluctantly suit-up again with an even more reluctantlier... reluctanter? Reluctantest? He must convince a reluctant Wolverine to - F*ck. Synopses are so f*cking stupid.\"\n\nIn addition to Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman in the title roles, Deadpool and Wolverine will see Morena Baccarin (Vanessa), Leslie Uggams (Blind Al), Rob Delaney (Peter), Brianna Hildebrand (Negasonic Teenage Warhead) And Shioli Kutsuna (Yukio) return as their respective characters, and they'll be joined by franchise newcomers Emma Corrin (The Crown) and Matthew Macfadyen (Succession), who will play a TV agent and Charles Xavier's evil counterpart, Cassandra Nova.\n\nShawn Levy directs Deadpool and Wolverine from a script by Ryan Reynolds, Rhett Reese, Paul Wernick, and Zeb Wells.\n\nThe movie is set to open in U.S. & Canadian theaters on July 26, and will be available in IMAX, RealD 3D, Dolby Cinema, 4DX, Cinemark XD and premium screens everywhere. {"uri": "8243407711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:39:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:39:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:38:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/national-international/deadpool-and-wolverine-set-for-highest-opening-of-an-r-rated-film/3371590/", "title": "'Deadpool and Wolverine' set for highest opening of an R-rated film", "body": "\"Deadpool and Wolverine\" also marks the first time an MCU film has garnered an R-rating from the Motion Picture Association.\n\nThe \"Merc with a Mouth\" returns to the big screen this weekend, and he's doing more than bringing an R-rating to Disney's Marvel Cinematic Universe.\n\n\"Deadpool and Wolverine,\" the third standalone feature starring Ryan Reynolds as the regenerating degenerate, is expected to tally between $160 million and $180 million at the domestic box office during its debut.\n\nThe film is already the best ticket pre-seller of 2024, according to Fandango -- and it's set to break a number of records during its opening weekend. Those marks include the highest domestic opening of 2024 and the biggest debut ever for an R-rated film.\n\nDisney and Pixar's \"Inside Out 2\" is currently the highest opener of the year at $154.2 million and the first \"Deadpool\" film's $132.4 million debut is the highest for any R-rated feature, according to data from Comscore.\n\n\"I think no question this is going to open as the largest R-rated movie of all time,\" said Mike Bowers, president and CEO of Harkins Theatres, a theater chain based in Arizona. \"And it's already one of the top presale movies historically for us.\"\n\n\"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is the 34th film to be released under the MCU banner and the first to garner an R-rating from the Motion Picture Association. The previous two Deadpool films, both rated R, were produced and released through 20th Century Fox. Disney acquired the company in 2019, bringing the X-Men and Fantastic Four back into the larger Marvel portfolio.\n\nLike previous entries in the MCU, \"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is benefitting from fan fervor. Audiences are eager to see the flick in its opening weekend in order to avoid spoilers. Disney has kept much of the film's content secret and provided limited press screenings prior to its debut.\n\nAnd Bowers expects audiences will keep coming back for more in the weeks after the film's opening.\n\n\"This is a film that there's so much happening, so many jokes and funny sequences that no one's gonna be able to eat just one, you know, they're gonna be back,\" he said.\n\nEllis Jacob, president and CEO of Cineplex, the largest movie theater chain in Canada, echoed Bower's thoughts. Jacob said \"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is filled with Easter eggs and audiences will return to try and see them all.\n\nHe also noted that many of those moviegoers are buying tickets for premium screenings, like IMAX, Dolby and ScreenX, which come at higher prices.\n\nMarvel has also collaborated with movie theaters to license merchandise like collectible popcorn buckets and drink containers that cinema operators expect will sell quickly. Concessions have always been the biggest money maker for theaters, and having limited edition items can drive even higher food and beverage sales.\n\nOf course, \"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is also an important release for the overall Marvel Cinematic Universe. Disney has \"eased off the gas pedal\" and planned fewer releases in the series that drove the global box office for more than a decade, said Shawn Robbins, founder and owner of Box Office Theory. He said Disney is trying to right the ship after a series of theatrical missteps and poor box office hauls, as well as an deluge of streaming content that overcrowded the market and overwhelmed even the MCU's biggest fans.\n\n\"Ultimately, as much as this is a Marvel movie, it may be viewed equally as a midsummer action comedy that stars personalities and brands that die-hard fans and casual viewers love,\" said Robbins. \"Reynolds and Jackman are a grand slam duo given their respective pop culture presences and friendly back-and-forth across social media and interviews. There's also a genuine curiosity about how the MCU's first R-rated film will play out and hold to the qualities which made the first two Deadpool films and [Jackman's 2017 Wolverine film] 'Logan' so popular.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcmiami.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC 6 South Florida"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Genres", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Genres", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Guides", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Movies/Guides", "news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 82}], "image": "https://media.nbcmiami.com/2024/07/108011558-1721882353958-deadpool_wolverine_Cropped.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&resize=1200%2C675", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762926", "eventUri": "eng-9762926", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.0980392156862746, "wgt": 152, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243357845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:03:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:03:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:01:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/10-must-read-deadpool-wolverine-155100172.html", "title": "10 Must-Read Deadpool (and Wolverine) Comics", "body": "\"Hearst Magazines and Yahoo may earn commission or revenue on some items through these links.\"\n\nANYONE WHO READ Deadpool's first appearance in 1991's New Mutants #98 would likely be utterly stunned by all the buzz surrounding's Disney's 2024 blockbuster Deadpool & Wolverine. Created by Rob Liefeld and introduced in an issue scripted by Fabian Nicieza, Deadpool was a not-so-subtle riff on Deathstroke the Terminator from DC Comics, right down to borrowing the secret identity -- DC's Slade Wilson inspired the Marvel character's name, Wade Wilson. Deadpool looked cool, but had little attitude to distinguish him from any other tough-guy hired killer.\n\nFast-forward thirty years later, and Deadpool has become not just one of the most popular characters in comics fandom, but also one of the most popular superheroes, period. Ryan Reynolds has embodied the smart-mouth, fourth-wall-breaking antihero so successfully that Deadpool & Wolverine has become one of the most highly anticipated films of the year, one that Marvel is hoping will reverse the trend of superhero fatigue.\n\nBut Deadpool's journey from unremarkable supporting character to pop culture's most self-aware stinker since Bugs Bunny didn't first happen on the screen. It happened in the comics, where writers such as Joe Kelly, Christopher Priest, and Gail Simone made Wade so much more than a dull, derivative killer.\n\nAnyone interested in seeing how Deadpool became the Merc with a Mouth, or want a few great Wolverine stories, would do well to check out these comics.\n\nThe New Mutants began as a spin-off of Uncanny X-Men, introducing a new class of adolescents recruited by Professor Charles Xavier after the mainline X-Men appeared to die in action. The stories written by Chris Claremont and Louise Simonson made the book a fan favorite. But despite some great characters and acclaimed runs, the book's sales flagged, at least until artist Rob Liefeld came on board.\n\nAs readers thrilled to Liefeld's high-octane, if fundamentally unsound, artwork, sales turned around. The popularity made Liefeld the main creative on the book, which he used to introduce new characters regularly, both in The New Mutants and its followup series X-Force. Given the frequency of new characters, many of similar styles and attitudes, Deadpool has little to distinguish him in his first appearance, where he's simply a hired killer who gets involved with the New Mutants and their leader, Cable. But Deadpool garnered enough interest to merit additional appearances, which allowed other writers to flesh him out.\n\nDespite what the press tour for Deadpool & Wolverine suggests, Deadpool is more of a Spider-Man fanboy in the comics. After all, just look at the costume he chose! That said, Wade and Logan do have a long history of clashes and team-ups, starting with 1994's Wolverine #88, written by the incomparable Larry Hama, penciled by Adam Kubert and Fabio Laguna, inked by Mark Farmer and Tim Townsend, colored by Marie Javins, and lettered by Pat Brosseau.\n\nHama's Wolverine run featured surprisingly well-observed character moments and over-the-top action, but \"It's D-D-Deadpool, Folks\" put the latter over the former. The light plot finds Deadpool and Wolverine crossing paths while in pursuit, Wolverine of a former colleague called Weapon X and Deadpool of his ex-girlfriend, Vanessa. Despite the flimsy motivations, Wolverine #88 features non-stop action, as the two assailants put their healing factors to the test, hacking and slashing at each other with anything they can find.\n\nFabian Nicieza began fleshing out Deadpool's sense of humor even while scripting Liefeld's pages, but no writer did more to establish the character's personality than Joe Kelly, who wrote several issues of Wade's first ongoing series. Although he only made a single off-hand metatextual joke during his run, telling the assassin Bullseye the issue number when they last met, Kelly transformed Deadpool into a tragic figure with a non-stop exterior monologue.\n\nThat characterization appears from the beginning of the series, in which Deadpool becomes an agent for a mysterious organization. With the help of his friend, the inventor Weasel, Deadpool takes the job out of the usual desire for cash but finds himself becoming sympathetic to those harmed by his missions. Kelly achieves the balance of mayhem and merriment through Ed McGuinness's cartoonish but clean character work, inked by Nathan Massengill and Norman Lee, colored by Chris Lichtner, and lettered by Richard Starkings and Dave Lanphear.\n\nBy the end of Joe Kelly's run on Deadpool, most of Wade's personality had been established. But Deadpool didn't start breaking the fourth wall until the short but excellent run by new writer Christopher Priest. Working with penciler Paco Diaz, inker Rodney Ramos, colorist Shannon Blanchard, and letterer Richard Starkings, Priest added the final missing piece to Deadpool, making him the hit he is today.\n\n\"Chapter X\" serves as both a recap and redirection for the Merc With a Mouth. Deadpool spends nearly all of the story trapped in a tank, where he suffers changes in reality, starting with his own body becoming elastic. As things grow worse, Deadpool assures himself that \"None of this is actually happening,\" blaming everything on a \"man with a typewriter.\" Once Thor's brother Loki gets involved, Deadpool sees things clearly and knows that he's in a comic book, changing his personality forever.\n\nAs reimagined by writer Rick Remender and artist Jerome Opena, Uncanny X-Force operated as the black ops wing of the X-Men, doing the dirty deeds that the mainline heroes couldn't do. In the first arc The Apocalypse Solution, X-Force takes on one of the most daring quests, killing the newly resurrected En Sabah Nur aka Apocalypse. But when Apocalypse comes back in a different form than expected, X-Force's resolve gets tested.\n\nAt first, Deadpool seems like an odd inclusion on the team, and not just because he isn't technically a mutant. Rather, Deadpool's constant banter makes him a strange fit in a darker team on a secret mission. Remender manages to balance the two tones, helping Deadpool work alongside complex characters like Psylocke and Archangel without sacrificing his sense of humor. Nothing demonstrates this balance better than a shocking scene in which Deadpool does the unthinkable to save Archangel from starvation.\n\nFew stories divide fans like Deadpool Kills the Marvel Universe, written by Cullen Bunn and illustrated by Dalibor Talajic. After a psychic attack goes horribly wrong, Deadpool's fourth-wall breaking goes to extremes, turning him nihilistic and sadistic. True to its title, Deadpool Kills the Marvel Universe depicts Wade killing all of the Marvel heroes without mercy or even joy. The book opens with him slaughtering the Fantastic Four and just goes on from there, far past the boundaries of good taste.\n\nMany have complained that Deadpool only succeeds in his rampage because Bunn writes Marvel heroes out of character. But anyone going to Deadpool Kills the Marvel Universe for consistent canon has already lost. Instead, the comic is best understood as an alternate reality thought exercise, imagining what it would look like if Deadpool got to kill all the heroes.\n\nIn \"Dead Presidents,\" Wade Wilson faces one of his most devious enemies: Richard Nixon. Tricky Dick hasn't come back to the land of the living alone. He's brought along every other former President who has shuffled off the mortal coil. The resurrected executives come courtesy of a disgruntled SHIELD agent with a superweapon. Free of any sense of reverence that would stay his hand, Wade jumps into action, sending the leaders of the free world back to Hell.\n\n\"Dead Presidents\" inaugurated one of the best and wackiest Deadpool runs of all time, written by Gerry Duggan and comedian Brian Posehn. Along with illustrator Tony Moore, colorist Val Staples, and letterer Joe Sabino, the writers embrace the storytelling possibilities offered by Deadpool's irreverent and over-the-top nature. \"Dead Presidents\" is the type of adventure that only Deadpool could have, for better or for worse.\n\nThe original Secret Wars crossover from 1984 was one of Marvel Comics's first major events, but it isn't particularly great. Designed in part to sell action figures, Secret Wars mostly consists of good guys and bad guys engaging in meaningless fights and nothing more. In other words, it's the perfect sort of story for Deadpool to invade and disrupt.\n\nWritten by Cullen Bunn, illustrated by Matteo Lolli, colored by Ruth Redmond, and lettered by Joe Sabino, Deadpool's Secret Wars retells the original story, this time with Deadpool added. The story hits the same major beats, just with Wade's one-liners and fourth-wall breaks to add humor to the otherwise dull plotting. Even better, the creative team tells a compelling and surprisingly moving tale that explains why Wade wasn't in the version we read decades ago.\n\nFrom the first trailers, Deadpool & Wolverine promised to be not just a team-up between the titular characters, but also a fond farewell to the 20th Century Fox superhero movies and Wade's inauguration into the MCU. These high stakes threaten to overwhelm the simple pleasures of seeing Deadpool work alongside Wolverine. More specifically, a Wolverine overwhelmed with guilt after failing to save his loved ones in his universe.\n\nIf Deadpool & Wolverine loses the plot in its multiversal adventure, at least we'll have Deadpool vs. Old Man Logan, a five-issue miniseries written by Declan Shalvey, illustrated by Mike Henderson, colored by Lee Loughridge, and lettered by Joe Sabino. Even though it co-stars an elderly Wolverine thrown back in time to the present, Deadpool vs. Old Man Logan keeps things simple and brutal. The two titular blade wielders try to save a young mutant from falling into the hands of duplicitous SHIELD agents, at least when they aren't trying to kill one another. Shalvey's lean plot leaves plenty of space for Henderson's sharp and expressive figure work, making for a pleasingly straightforward read.\n\nThe cover of 2022's Wolverine #23 recreates the cover of Wolverine #88 from decades earlier, with the robotic baddie Danger impaling both Wolverine and Deadpool instead of just Deadpool stabbing Wolverine. Lest anyone call out the later comic as a rip-off, keep in mind that both images come from illustrator Adam Kubert, who returned to the characters as the regular artist on the latest Wolverine ongoing.\n\nDespite the consistent visuals, much has changed for both leads. Not only is Deadpool far more popular in 2022 than he was in 1994, but Wolverine is now a citizen of Krakoa, a sovereign nation only for mutants. Krakoa dominated X-Men stories from 2019 to earlier this year, and \"Old Haunts\" is no different. Kubert and writer Benjamin Percy, colorist Frank Martin, and letterer Cory Petit send Deadpool to hassle Wolverine for an invitation to Krakoa (despite the fact that he isn't a mutant), leading to yet another reluctant team-up.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:_The_Animated_Series", {"uri": "2024-07-433498255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:42:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:42:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:42:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/english/movie-reviews/deadpool-wolverine/movie-review/112009734.cms", "title": "Deadpool & Wolverine Movie Review: Ryan Reynolds brings the house down in this bloody spectacle", "body": "Story: Deadpool, aka Wade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds), pulls Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) back from the dead to save his own world from a powerful and diabolical enemy. But before they can save the world, will they end up killing each other?\n\nReview: Deadpool has always been known for his wisecracks and witty comebacks, but this time, Ryan Reynolds (also a co-writer) takes it up several notches, making this Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) tentpole a riotous affair. His comedic punches are even more impactful than the physical ones, both of which land with an impact.\n\nDirector Shawn Levy, hailed by many as the saviour of the MCU's troubled fortunes, delivers a self-aware, self-deprecating gag fest from the very first scene. This franchise outing spares no one, poking fun at everything - from Disney's takeover of Fox to Hugh Jackman's seemingly eternal association with the franchise as Wolverine. Even Captain America and Mad Max aren't safe from Deadpool's relentless jabs. It's a no-holds-barred chaotic comedy that pulls out all the stops, and we are definitely not complaining.\n\nThe plot is straightforward yet engaging: one insanely powerful enemy against two superheroes, one of whom is desperate to become an Avenger. Deadpool's world, consisting of the nine people he truly cares about, is in danger, and to save it, he ropes in a variant of the late James 'Logan' Howlett or the Wolverine. Logan, now stuck with Deadpool's incessant chatter, finds himself in the Void, facing the formidable villain Cassandra Nova (Emma-Louise Corrin) alongside a slew of other superheroes, leading to bloody battles and relentless action.\n\nRyan Reynolds is the heartbeat of this movie. We expect Deadpool to be unfiltered and offensive, but Reynolds elevates it to another level. His relentless banter fuels the madness of this installment, making it clear that Deadpool is an equal-opportunity offender. Reynolds' unhinged portrayal of Deadpool is a testament to the franchise's desperate need for a course correction. The film shatters the fourth wall and even takes on the fans, with Deadpool addressing them as nerds and making cheeky comments about their \"special sock\" for the most anticipated fight scenes. This back-to-basics approach reminds us that at its core, this franchise is based on a comic book after all and should never have been more complicated.\n\nHugh Jackman plays it cool as Wolverine, but his character shows signs of weariness, which Deadpool humorously addresses by suggesting the MCU will keep Jackman in the role until he's 90. Jackman takes the joke in his stride, and their on-screen chemistry flows organically. The mindless banter, sexual innuendos, and tension amid the bromance are complemented by intense action and bloodshed. There's enough and more of it, but one wonders when to really feel worried about any of the characters because almost everyone is always immortal. Well almost. The film boasts spectacular visuals typical of a big-screen outing, and at just over two hours, it seldom feels like a drag. There are many noteworthy cameos, but we aren't the ones to give spoilers of any kind. Emma Corrin stands out as the evil Cassandra Nova, her petite frame belying the raw power she wields.\n\nWhether you're a fan or not, 'Deadpool & Wolverine' keeps you engaged with its constant stream of action and humor. It helps to be familiar with the legacy characters and storyline (as messy and complicated as it may be) to fully appreciate the experience, especially when watching it with an enthusiastic audience. 'Deadpool & Wolverine' breaks barriers and goes where other MCU films haven't, capturing nostalgia, humour, and most importantly, delivering oodles of entertainment. This is exactly what the franchise needs to stay relevant and enjoyable.", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Times of India"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ronak_kotecha@timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "name": "Ronak Kotecha", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadpool_(video_game)", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-07-433453959", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:02:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:02:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:02:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.radiotimes.com/movies/scifi/lady-deadpool-wolverine-blake-lively-explained/", "title": "Who plays Lady Deadpool in Deadpool & Wolverine?", "body": "It's fair to say that Deadpool & Wolverine is a film that's built around some pretty major cameos.\n\nFrom massive MCU stars returning with a twist, to iconic comic book characters played by A-listers, to welcome appearances for beloved heroes from Fox's slate of Marvel movies, the movie is sure to delight fans with some of the big names it wheels out - with director Shawn Levy revealing that some of the stars had not been predicted by fans.\n\nAnd there had certainly been no shortage of predicting. Ahead of the release, one of the big questions on fans's minds was the matter of who might be drafted in to play Lady Deadpool, a female variant of the superhero who had long been confirmed to be making an appearance.\n\nThere were all sorts of suggestions as to who might be playing her - with some fans even speculating that pop superstar Taylor Swift could be taking on the role.\n\nWell, now that the film is out, the identity of the character has been revealed - read on for everything you need to know.\n\nWho plays Lady Deadpool in Deadpool & Wolverine?\n\nIn the end, it's Blake Lively who takes on the role of Lady Deadpool. Of course, this isn't too much of a surprise - the former Gossip Girl star has been married to Ryan Reynolds since 2012, and so it makes perfect sense that she would be involved in the film.\n\nIndeed, Lively had been one of the most commonly identified stars when fans were guessing who might play the role, so plenty of people will feel vindicated about their predictions.\n\nDespite her appearance in the film - which comes when Wade Wilson and Logan are confronted by a huge army of Deadpool variants - we never actually sees Lively's face, as she is wearing her mask the entire time.\n\nHer identity is therefore not revealed until the credits - and it turns out she's not the only big name hiding behind a Deadpool mask in that scene.\n\nMatthew McConaughey is credited as playing Cowboy Deadpool, and although we don't see his face, we do briefly hear his distinctive Southern drawl.\n\nBut both those big stars are upstaged by one Deadpool variant who seems destined to emerge from the film as its breakout star: Peggy the Dog, who plays Dogpool.", "source": {"uri": "radiotimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Radio Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-433194595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:12:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:12:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:11:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://beebom.com/lady-deadpool-powers-abilities/", "title": "Lady Deadpool in Deadpool 3: Powers, Abilities & Who Plays the Role", "body": "Blake Lively is rumored to play the character in the movie, but it is yet to be confirmed.\n\nThe fandom has hugely praised the previous Deadpool films, thanks to the epic storylines and Ryan Reynolds's legendary comic timing. But no argue the fact that Deadpool 3 will be the best of the franchise as it involves Hugh Jackman as Wolverine, and the trailers have already revealed the onscreen chemistry he will share with the foul-mouthed Deadpool. On top of everything, Deadpool & Wolverine also features a female counterpart of our lead hero. Let's find out who is the female Deadpool aka Lady Deadpool.\n\nWho Is Female Deadpool\n\nFemale Deadpool's real name is Wanda Wilson, and she belongs to the alternate reality Earth-3010. She's a mercenary who will take up even the toughest assignments for money. Additionally, Wanda Wilson is known for her never-ending love for junk food and television (She's basically me....if, of course, you take out the superhero part).\n\nWhen Earth-3010 became a victim of fascism, and everyone was forced to spend their lives as per the government, Congress and the top generals got split. Some states also started seeking independence. This is when we get to truly know the heavily scarred Lady Deadpool, who stands against General America's troop of loyalists in Washington D.C. This wasn't their first meeting, though, as Wanda Wilson and General America had crossed paths before. The latter had his right arm mutilated in the conflict.\n\nGeneral America already had to settle his old score with Lady Deadpool, and luckily, he got the chance the second time. However, before he can harm Wanda, Deadpool from Earth-616 shows up and helps her to knock out General America. After that, O.G. Deadpool reveals his plan to save the Multiverse to Wanda, and without thinking even for a minute, she agrees.\n\nLady Deadpool Joins the Deadpool Corps\n\nThe Contemplator chose our favorite Deadpool, Wade Wilson, to hire the Deadpools from different alternate worlds and build a Deadpool Corps that will fight against consciousness-absorbing Awareness. As instructed, Deadpool of Earth-616 hires Kidpool, Headpool, Dogpool, and, of course, Lady Deadpool. However, the chosen ones must prove their worthiness in front of the Elders to become the official members of the Corps.\n\nThe fight began, and the female Deadpool eventually killed the enemy with her sword. Following the win, the Elders rewarded each member of the Corps with a ring. The special gifts allowed the Corps to summon any Elder of the universe and ask them for their help with whatever they wanted. Besides that, the Elders also gave them their ship, Bea Arthur.\n\nAs part of the Deadpool Corps, Lady Deadpool and the other members had to travel to different realities to fight the evil forces. The Corps fought their final battle with the Evil Deadpool Corps and sacrificed their lives in the process.\n\nWanda Wilson, Aka. Lady Deadpool's incredible healing factor makes her look similar to Wolverine. She can heal any wound within seconds and can even regrow the missing body parts with a quick speed. The healing factor also helps her brain cells to work more efficiently than any other human. It also enhances her immunity and protects Lady Deadpool from infections and diseases.\n\n2. Immune to Poison\n\nIt's quite challenging for the enemies to drug and intoxicate Wanda as her body is resistant to most of the drugs and poisons. However, we can't say she cannot be intoxicated ever as drugs such as tranquilizers can affect her if given in heavy dosages.\n\n3. Superhuman Strength\n\nLady Deadpool can perform any physical activity for several days without getting tired, even for a bit. Her agility, reflexes, and bodily coordination make her superior even to the athletes.\n\nWho Plays Lady Deadpool in the Deadpool 3\n\nEvery Deadpool fan has been waiting for the big reveal of the actress behind the Lady Deadpool. {"uri": "2024-07-433530898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:15:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:15:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:40:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/review-deadpool-wolverine-create-a-new-level-of-awesome-together/article", "title": "Review: 'Deadpool & Wolverine' create a new level of awesome together", "body": "A scene from 'Deadpool & Wolverine' courtesy of 20th Century Studios and Marvel\n\n'Deadpool & Wolverine' is everything fans want and more as the Marvel heroes reluctantly join forces to keep the world from ending.\n\nEven Deadpool acknowledges that when Disney bought 20 Century Fox there were definite concerns the family company may not want to be attached to the foul-mouthed assassin for hire. Lucky for everyone, Marvel wanted the Merc with the Mouth back in the fold and now that they're under the same umbrella, the door is open for the inclusion of even more of the studio's superheroes and villains - a previous failing Deadpool was unafraid of calling out. However, those many possibilities were nearly a moot point once the greatest wish on fans' lips and most anticipated team-up was finally confirmed: Marvel Studios presents Deadpool & Wolverine.\n\nWade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) is not in a great place in his life, but a hero answers the call when he's needed... or at least that's what he's heard. So, when the TVA comes knocking on his door and it turns out not to be for the many times he messed with the timeline, no one is more shocked than Wade. However, what Mr. Paradox (Matthew Macfadyen) tells him convinces him it's time to squeeze back into the red suit, so Deadpool can save the world - no joke. But first, he needs to find Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) because the plan doesn't work without him.\n\nThe series' soundtracks are always great, pairing unexpected classics with ultra-violent scenes. However, this movie arguably features the best opening credit sequence to a superhero movie, redefining everyone's first reference when they hear the selected NSYNC hit from this day forward. It's fast-paced, high-energy and an excellent way to set the tone for the franchise's second sequel. The picture then has no choice but to deaccelerate a bit, bringing the focus back to the narrative and Deadpool's quest to save the world. Yet, it still doesn't miss an opening for a pop culture reference, the chance to curse or an opportunity to poke fun at its new parent company. It also delivers the R-rated Wolverine dialogue fans always knew was lurking beneath the surface of the PG scripts.\n\nWhile the movie continues to offer its treasured brand of off-colour heroism, the one thing that sets this chapter apart from its predecessors are the cameos. As Deadpool previously noted, they could only afford the lower value Marvel characters prior to the merge. Now, there are recognizable actors and characters sprinkled throughout the film, reviving many personalities from earlier movies, including some very exciting and unexpected faces. Though the best guest appearances come in the latter half of the picture, reintroducing long-gone yet beloved superheroes and reconfirming some ideas are better left never reaching audiences.\n\nThe narrative also feels different from previous movies. Although it still centres on a personal journey - Wade rediscovering his self-confidence and Logan's search for redemption - it lacks the off-the-wall quality of the other films, which is likely because of the lack of variety in the story's isolated location. However, this does allow for almost all of the focus to be placed on the first-time (and hopefully not the last) team-up between Deadpool and Wolverine. Being each other's complete opposites, they're in constant conflict, leading to them repeatedly stabbing each other on more than occasion, including an epic fight in a very confined space. But neither of them is going to die from their injuries, so it seems better (and more entertaining) to let them work out their differences. Conversely, Dogpool, a.k.a. Mary Puppins, has the ability to quell even the most violent of mobs, in spite of her appearance being an acquired taste. Note, Peggy the Dog was actually named Britain's ugliest pooch before gaining stardom and winning over Marvel fans.\n\nAnd since you'll be staying till the end of the movie for the post-credit scene anyways, look for a special \"thank you\" listed near the end.", "source": {"uri": "digitaljournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Digital Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243408055", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:39:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:39:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:38:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://sea.ign.com/deadpool-wolverine/218628/news/ryan-reynolds-reveals-alpha-cop-an-intentionally-bad-fake-movie-that-would-have-switched-to-deadpool", "title": "Ryan Reynolds Reveals Alpha Cop, an 'Intentionally Bad' Fake Movie That Would Have Switched to Deadpool & Wolverine 5 Minutes In", "body": "This post might contain affiliation links. If you buy something through this post, the publisher may get a share of the sale.\n\nRyan Reynolds has revealed one discarded plan for Deadpool & Wolverine that would surely have shocked cinemagoers had it ever become reality.\n\nSpeaking on the First We Feast YouTube channel, Deadpool actor Reynolds said the original idea for Deadpool & Wolverine was to shoot a fake movie called Alpha Cop that was \"intentionally bad.\" It would have been about two cops who share a brain, and a mock poster would have carried the slogan: \"Alpha Cop. Two cops. One brain. All balls.\"\n\nAlpha Cop would then have hit theaters and, five minutes in, switch over to Deadpool & Wolverine.\n\n\"The original idea with this movie was to shoot a fake movie called Alpha Cop that was intentionally bad,\" Reynolds said. \"I even had one of the posters made. It was about two guys who were sharing one brain, and together they make the ultimate cop. And the poster says: 'Alpha Cop. Two cops. One brain. All balls.'\n\n\"It was meant to be kind of like horrible, so 10 people in America would go to see this movie on opening weekend. Five minutes into the movie the Marvel logo would flip up and it would actually be Deadpool & Wolverine.\"\n\nObviously, the Alpha Cop idea didn't end up happening, but it's fun to imagine people sitting down to watch what they thought was going to be a terrible buddy cop movie only to find out they were watching Deadpool & Wolverine instead. Perhaps Alpha Cop will make a cameo appearance should Deadpool 4 eventually see the light of day.\n\nReynolds and co-star Hugh Jackman, who plays Wolverine, have spent the last month or so touring the globe promoting Deadpool & Wolverine, which is the only MCU movie of 2024. IGN has plenty on the film, including our Deadpool & Wolverine review, interviews with director Shawn Levy and Marvel chief Kevin Feige, with more to come.\n\nWesley is the UK News Editor for IGN. Find him on Twitter at @wyp100. {"uri": "8243799077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:18:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:18:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:17:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.vulture.com/article/deadpool-and-wolverine-review-roundup.html", "title": "Critics Agree: Deadpool & Wolverine Is Corporate Fun", "body": "Marvel has done many a crossover episode (all the Avengers movies, that one civil war between two supes, random cameos from the Marvel Cinematic Universe Multiverse). But a crossover episode joking about butt stuff and blow with two of its most beloved characters? Marvel hasn't done that until now. Deadpool & Wolverine arrived for critics' viewing pleasure just ahead of its July 26 release, giving us the opportunity to dive into reviews about the Ryan Reynolds- and Hugh Jackman-led superhero comedy. Critics say the new popcorn movie knows just how to twiddle diehards, what with its fourth-wall-breaking, referential humor that winkingly skewers the MCU, the actors themselves, and, most crucially, the corporate merger between Disney's Marvel and 20th Century Fox, which brought Wolverine into the House of Mouse. Despite its confusing multiverse plotlines and self-aware \"I'm here to make money\" identity, critics can (mostly) agree on one thing: It's funny. More reactions, below.\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine isn't a particularly good movie -- I'm not even sure it is a movie -- but it's so determined to beat you down with its incessant irreverence that you might find yourself submitting to it. The picture arrives, of course, at a fallow time for Marvel after a string of duds and an abortive attempt to introduce a new superhero phase following the climactic, stage-clearing (and absurdly lucrative) battles of Avengers: Endgame. It's something of a relief that this new movie isn't trying to reboot or revamp or extend or set the stage for anything. (There is a good joke about how it ties into a specific episode of Loki, and it probably does, but I'm not gonna bother to find out.) Honestly, it appears to exist solely to make money. The film tries to wink its way out of its nonsense plot -- a convoluted setup that involves Deadpool finding a live Wolverine in another universe so that he can save his own universe before it's destroyed by a mysterious organization called the Time Variance Authority (TVA), led by an extremely hammy Matthew Macfadyen. It acknowledges its own cravenness, and that transparency can be preferable to stolid sincerity.\" -- Bilge Ebiri, Vulture\n\n\"The script is upfront about what Disney wouldn't allow Reynolds & Co. to show. Cocaine is prominently mentioned, but nobody does any; butt stuff is described but not depicted; there's homoerotic horseplay and wordplay but no actual sexual person-play. That being said, the writers get more latitude than I assumed they'd get when it comes to criticisms of Disney running the MCU into the ground and off in multiple, incompatible directions post Endgame. 'Welcome to the MCU, by the way,' Wade tells Logan. 'You're joining at a low point.'\" -- Matt Zoller Seitz, Roger Ebert\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine -- which might more accurately have been called Deadpool & His Sidekick Wolverine -- is sometimes very funny, at times a bit flat, and so filled with callbacks to other X-Men and Marvel movies that your head might explode, not in a good way.\" -- Caryn James, BBC\n\n\"The subtle squeamishness over sex and sexuality is one thing. But considered in conjunction with half-assed punchlines about Deadpool fearing being 'canceled by the woke mob' or being over 'Gen Z's trauma-dumping,' it seems Disney is moving the Merc with a Mouth toward conservatism. Perhaps a movie meant to to placate the same audience that gnashed their teeth over the last Star Wars trilogy's -- and The Acolyte's -- focus on marginalized characters over the previously predominantly white, straight, and male heroes. The jokes at the expense of Disney, Marvel, and Kevin Feige play the same way in effect. Sure, they seem initially provocative, with Deadpool calling out Marvel's missteps or Feige's rules for MCU movies. But consider how notoriously controlling these studios are over this IP. Consider Disney and Marvel's history of squelching queer representation on-screen. And you can see how Wade, who is supposed to titillate us with his unapologetic hot takes, feels less like he's breaking fresh ground and more like he's parroting the well-worn gripes of Twitter trolls.\" -- Kristy Puchko, Mashable\n\n\"But in the end, Deadpool & Wolverine is a movie about corporate mergers, about intellectual property, about the ways that the business of Hollywood battles the creative process. It is a film about how anything that was ever successful in Hollywood is made to repeat that same song and dance endlessly, how a bloated and risk-averse industry can't let well enough alone, how nobody is ever really dead anymore, how the world is always ending but the story is never allowed to finish.\" -- Alissa Wilkinson, The New York Times\n\n\"Dwindling grosses, audience ennui, critical maulings -- well, if this is the last hurrah of Marvel it's going down all punchlines blazing. Ebulliently directed by Shawn Levy (Night at the Museum), this is a hyperactive cheese dream that brings together two of Marvel's best characters and a supporting cast who will have nerds frothing at the mouth.\" -- Ed Potton, The Times\n\n\"As bountiful as the action scenes are here, the jokes are the sturdiest part of Deadpool & Wolverine (and if it seems like I'm giving too many of them away, don't worry, there are loads more to go around). That's because the plot is a lumpy stew of familiar elements, given minimal narrative clarity despite the reams of expository technobabble spouted by Matthew Macfadyen's Mr. Paradox.\" -- David Rooney, The Hollywood Reporter\n\n\"Hey, you're either the butt of the joke or you're the studio waggling Reynolds's keister at the lens while he pokes fun at your own corporate mergers. Wisecracking about his, and their, mistakes like he's trying to win couples therapy, Deadpool represents what mainstream Marvel flicks couldn't do: make a hard R-rated movie with more curses per minute than a convention of witches. He's what they have to do to win back an audience who's outgrown them.\" -- Amy Nicholson, The Washington Post\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine is as much fun as you can conceivably have at a corporate merger meeting. It's tedious, yet, occasionally, Ryan Reynolds's fourth-wall-allergic \"Merc with a Mouth\" will pass a note around the table with a penis drawn on it, and everyone can have a quiet, little chuckle to themselves.\" -- Clarisse Loughrey, The Independent\n\n\"Audiences (and Disney) may well demand it, though this singular mutant satire works best as an irreverent homage to what's come before, as opposed to the prototype for future superhero movies.\" -- Peter Debruge, Variety\n\n\"It assumes that everyone in the audience is well-versed in the boardroom maneuvers of 20th Century Fox and Disney and will get jokes about what \"Feige said\" (a reference to producer Kevin Feige). When Wilson sees a skull under an Ant-Man helmet, he yuks that Paul Rudd has finally aged. There's also a crack about Jackman's recent divorce. When things get a little too Mad Max-ish, he worries about being in the wrong IP. Who is the audience for this? Entertainment lawyers who watch TMZ?\" -- Jordan Hoffman, Entertainment Weekly", "source": {"uri": "vulture.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Vulture"}, "authors": [{"uri": "zoe_guy@vulture.com", {"uri": "2024-07-433804895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:32:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:32:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.looper.com/1628811/deadpool-wolverine-end-credits-scenes-explained/", "title": "Deadpool & Wolverine's Very Different Post Credits Scenes, Explained", "body": "It goes without saying that \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is extremely different from anything else we've gotten in the Marvel Cinematic Universe thus far. It features far more profanity and gory violence than people usually see in MCU movies, which up until now have been relegated to PG-13 territory, with one sexual joke, in particular, creating a problem for Kevin Feige. However, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" does adhere to certain MCU standards in other ways, including offering a couple of treats for fans who stay through the credits.\n\nThe first isn't really a mid-credits scene, instead offering a retrospective on the history of Marvel movies made under 20th Century Fox's banner. As the credits roll, behind-the-scenes footage showcasing actors from the \"X-Men\" and \"Fantastic Four\" movies begins to play, all set to Green Day's \"Good Riddance (Time of Your Life).\" There's even a quick interview clip of Ryan Reynolds seemingly from the set of \"X-Men Origins: Wolverine,\" speaking about his enthusiasm for getting to play the Merc with a Mouth. That film may not have been well-received, but it shows just how far Reynolds and superhero movies in general have come in the past decade and a half.\n\nFor a \"Deadpool\" movie, the clip show is surprisingly sentimental, reflecting on actors cast in superhero movies all the way back to the early 2000s. But before you go thinking \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" ends on an entirely somber note, don't worry. {"uri": "2024-07-433712824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:02:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:02:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:00:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.cbr.com/kevin-feige-sequels-defense/", "title": "Kevin Feige Defends Movie Sequels as 'Absolute Pillar of the Industry'", "body": "Like many Hollywood franchises, the Marvel Cinematic Universe stands accused of making too many sequels, with movie lovers crying out for more original movies. However, Marvel's president believes sequels are a \"pillar\" of the film industry and necessary for its growth.\n\nSpeaking with Variety, Kevin Feige addressed the concept of sequels and their place in Hollywood. Feige was asked about his movie career and the thinking behind creating universes like the MCU, which has been going strong since 2008. The Marvel boss revealed he's been a fan of sequels since his early days in the movie business, liking the idea of world-building and expanding on character arcs from original films.\n\nRelated\n\nEternals 2 Gets Disappointing Update From Kevin Feige\n\nMarvel Studios president Kevin Feige updates Marvel Cinematic Universe fans on the future of its Eternals franchise.\n\nClose\n\n\"I always liked the world-building and being able to return to characters,\" he said. \"I was always excited for sequels. I was never cynical or rolling my eyes the way people still do today for some reason, even though there've been sequels since the '30s and they're an absolute pillar of the industry. To me, those were always what I enjoyed most, the notion that something I loved was returning and it would expand on what I loved about it.\"\n\n\"To me, those were always what I enjoyed most, the notion that something I loved was returning and it would expand on what I loved about it.\"\n\nFeige has served as a primary producer on MCU projects since the cinematic universe's inception, overseeing several franchises such as Iron Man, Avengers and Captain America. The MCU has come under fire in recent years for lacking originality due to its penchant for sequels, with the high content output triggering superhero fatigue among fans. Recent MCU box office flops such as Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania and The Marvels have been partly attributed to said fatigue.\n\nRelated\n\n'Best Characters in Hollywood History': Kevin Feige Hails Deadpool & Wolverine Casting\n\nEXCLUSIVE: Kevin Feige gives high praise to Ryan Reynolds' Deadpool and Hugh Jackman's Wolverine.\n\nDisney recently outlined a plan to reduce Marvel's film and TV output in the coming years amid concerns of too many sequels and superhero fatigue. During a Disney earnings call earlier this year, CEO Bob Iger claimed the output reduction was being done to prioritize quality over quantity. \"We're slowly going to decrease volume and go to probably about two TV series a year instead of what had become four, and reduce our film output from maybe four a year to two or at the maximum three. And we're working hard on what that path is, we've got a couple of good films in '25, and then we're heading to more Avengers, which we're extremely excited about,\" he said. His earnings call comments came a few months after expressing his belief Disney makes too many sequels.\n\nOnly One MCU Movie Will Be Released in 2024\n\nThe content reduction plan is already being executed, with the Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman-led Deadpool & Wolverine being the lone MCU movie release this year. Meanwhile, Echo and Agatha All Along are the only TV series debuting in 2024.\n\nEarly indications point to Deadpool & Wolverine generating a big bounceback for the MCU at the box office, while the team-up blockbuster has generated encouraging reviews. Though Deadpool & Wolverine is the third Deadpool film, it isn't a threequel, considering it's the first to take place in the MCU, with the previous entries happening in the 20th Century Fox era.\n\nDeadpool & Wolverine opens in theaters on Jul. 26.\n\nSource: Variety\n\nDeadpool & Wolverine\n\n9\n\n10\n\nAction\n\nSci-Fi\n\nComedy\n\nWolverine joins the \"merc with a mouth\" in the third installment of the Deadpool film franchise.\n\nDirector Shawn Levy\n\nRelease Date July 26, 2024\n\nCast Ryan Reynolds , Hugh Jackman , Matthew Macfadyen , Morena Baccarin , Rob Delaney , Karan {"uri": "2024-07-433789895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:06:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:06:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:51:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/entertainment/movie-review/deadpool-and-wolverine-review-ryan-reynolds-hugh-jackman-full-movie-review-and-rating-2631603", "title": "Deadpool & Wolverine review: Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman's overbearing fan service", "body": "New Delhi: Hear me out! Deadpool & Wolverine is watchable. In fact, it feels more like a warm hug to the X-Men series. But the movie becomes a bit overbearing and loses its momentum halfway through. As a whole, the underwhelming aspects do not matter. Especially when you are treated to some ROFL jokes by Deadpool. Flaunting himself as 'Marvel Jesus,' the superhero in a TVA-sponsored brand-new suit is a delight until you get tired of it.\n\nDeadpool & Wolverine story\n\nWade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) isn't exactly discontent with his post-Deadpool 2 life as a car salesman with Peter (Rob Delaney) with Blind Al (Leslie Uggams) as his roomie. He's fine with occasionally spending time with the X-Men's Negasonic Teenage Warhead (Brianna Hildebrand) and Colossus (Stefan Kapi\u010di\u0107) and maintaining a friendship with his ex-fianc\u00e9e Vanessa (Morena Baccarin). Now that Wade knows he's part of the action, he feels he could do more if Kevin Feige let him join the Avengers like Captain America or Thor.\n\nThe movie's rushed introduction of TVA agent Mr. Paradox (Matthew Macfadyen) in the first act to explain the significance of one universe's Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) may confuse rather than clarify how Deadpool & Wolverine fits into the broader MCU narrative.\n\nFreeing themselves from the clutches of the supervillain Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrines)- the self-acclaimed queen of the void, uniting for the ultimate showdown, saving Deadpool's universe and the heroic duo's constant banter makes the whole plot seem more like a fan service. It's neither bad nor iconic.\n\nLet's skip to the good part...\n\nLogan always keeps you wanting for more with his serious demeanour and mean remarks. Hugh's return is heartfelt with his sharp dialogue delivery hitting the mark. Also, prepare yourself for some ultime Wolverine thirst traps. Deadpool & Wolverine's gripping climax is appreciable too.\n\nRyan Reynolds is Ryan Reynolds and that is -being a Marvel fan-girl. Undoubtedly, Logan's reclamation is the backbone of an indestructible heroic team. Despite the messy action, the choreography in the initial hour is mind-blowing. With an immensely enjoyable relay of cameos, the fan service doesn't fall on the bad side of the review spectrum.\n\nEmma Corrins is absolutely great as Cassandra, especially when she is fingering the brains out of everyone. Her frigid look is no less than her twin brother Professor X.\n\nFor pro-Disney peeps, there's a gazillion of humour waiting for you. And giving zero spoilers, the Deadpool jokes are exceptional. His fetish for the enemies-to-friends trope with Logan is cartoonish. But it is the silly things that will make you chuckle in this multiverse of madness.\n\nWhere's the flaw?\n\nThe film felt pretty fair to watch but despite Hugh's marvellous acting skills, Wolverine's role feels 'meh'. At least until he puts on his suit. The lazy writing couldn't do justice to his redemption arc. Of course, his presence feels overshadowed. In a personal rant, Marvel needs to invest their brains in directing their action sequences. The fight scenes do not seem smooth and one might feel the urge to just skip it instead. The transitions don't meet the benchmark, with multiple cuts in between them, putting a huge question mark on their million-dollar VFX. What's equally surprising is that in many instances the satire isn't as sharp or well-timed as in the other parts of the Deadpool series.\n\nWatch Deadpool & Wolverine if you are up for a cameo fest and some cool and politically-incorrect Deadpool jokes.", "source": {"uri": "news9live.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News9live"}, "authors": [{"uri": "vanshika_singh@news9live.com", "name": "https://images.news9live.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Deadpool-and-Wolverine-2.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762926", "eventUri": "eng-9762926", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-07-433821069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:08:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:08:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.nj.com/entertainment/2024/07/heres-what-no-one-understands-about-deadpool-wolverine.html", "title": "Here's what no one understands about 'Deadpool & Wolverine'", "body": "Stop me if you've heard this before. The Marvel Cinematic Universe is dire need of saving, the Avengers are nowhere to be found and the biggest name in entertainment is once again relying on an unlikely hero.\n\nYes, it is happening again. Marvel Studios, the theatrical juggernaut that once churned out billion-dollar hits as easily as Wade Wilson spits out f-bombs, is in its forth year of chasing the cultural and critical highs reached by 2019's \"Avengers: Endgame.\" The last 11 films haven't quite done it, the 10 Disney Plus shows definitely haven't done it and superhero fatigue is at an all-time high. It's no longer a question of if these movies will make a billion dollars. It's a question of if these movies will actually be made.\n\nNow Marvel is turning to a beloved character that once seemed like he'd never fit in the sanitized, family-friendly Disney confines of the MCU. The gulliest, goriest anti-hero of them all. The Merc with a Mouth. Deadpool.\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine\" comes to theaters on Friday, the first and only MCU film of 2024 -- a major departure for a studio that used to regularly release three movies every year. It brings with it not only the studio's first R-rating, but two absolutely beloved characters who enter the MCU thanks to Disney's purchase of 21st Century Fox.\n\nREAD MORE: All 34 Marvel movies, including 'Deadpool and Wolverine,' ranked\n\nAs a self-admitted comic book nerd who anticipates these movies with nearly religious fervor and obsesses over every detail, I spend much of my time watching these movies and discussing them focusing on what they are leading to. How does this connect to the next movie? Which characters are they teasing? Are the Avengers coming back? But with the franchise in unprecidentedly rough shape, I shifted my mentality as I sat down for \"Deadpool & Wolverine.\" I stopped thinking about what this movie meant for the future of the MCU and just tried to enjoy it.\n\nAnd holy crap. Did I enjoy it.\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is one of the funniest, bloodiest, most meta and self-referential movies I have ever seen. It's irreverent, yet heartfelt at times even moving. It spends more time making fun of the Marvel Cinematic Universe than it does trying to join it, and writes a love letter to Fox Studios comic book movies I didn't know we needed. Yes, there are cameos that even I didn't know were coming. Yes, I screamed in the theater when ***** came on screen.\n\nBut the core of this movie is its titular characters, and the actors that were born to play them. There would be no Deadpool movies without Ryan Reynolds, who somehow makes this sadistic psychopath charming, and seeing him play in the expanded Marvel sandbox is exhillerating. Bringing Hugh Jackman out of retirement to reprise the role of Wolverine could have been an absolute disaster that ruined his beautiful final act in 2017's \"Logan.\" But it's a complete joy to see everyone's favorite X-Men member in his comic-accurate blue and yellow suit and somehow earn even more pathos as a character.\n\nThe chemistry between these two characters is absolutely electric, and the buddy cop/road trip comedy vibes truly make this feel like \"Planes, Trains and Automobiles\" with superheroes. And the fight scenes, which relied less blatently on CGI than previous films from this studio, were plainly fun as hell. I could see Deadpool's katanas clash with Wolverine's adamantium claws all day long.\n\nIs the plot convoluted? Yes! It's a comic book movie. Even the absolute best movies in this genre aren't revered for their plots. The first two Deadpool movies weren't winning any best screenplay Oscars and they were still beloved. Hell, spend enough time thinking about the plot of \"The Dark Knight,\" widely considered the best comic book movie ever, and you'll find yourself scratching your head.\n\nHere's what no one seems to understand about \"Deadpool & Wolverine,\" and the genre writ large. We come to this place for superhero magic. Ridiculous action scenes that look like they're pulled right from the pages of a comic book. References to comic book lore that make us feel like we're kids again, even if some us weren't even kids when the Marvel Cinematic Universe launched in 2008. Cameos. Yes. We love cameos! Humor that points out how ridiculous this genre is -- and yes, how corporate and confusingly intertwined this has all gotten. Deadpool repeatedly joking about post-endgame Marvel's struggles (even specifically trashing the multiverse storyline) is exactly what I want from a Deadpool movie. I laughed so much my face hurt by the end.\n\nI'm not saying we shouldn't be criticial of superhero movies, I've ripped Marvel plenty in recent years. But this movie isn't for you, maybe you just don't like comic book movies anymore! And that's okay.\n\nDid \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" blaze the trail forward for the MCU as much as I would have liked? Probably not. But after years of people complaining about how overly interconnected all these movies are, it was actually refreshing to watch a movie that was surprisingly self-contained.\n\nIt's not 100% clear where the MCU is going from here. And for once, I don't care. I loved the hell out of this movie, enough that I already have a ticket to see it again. I wasn't worrying about the franchise's path during the MCU's rise in the 2010s, I was just along for the ride. There wasn't a clear-cut direction until things really coalessed following \"Avengers: Age of Ultron\" in 2015 -- things just got retconned and rexplained to fit all together in the run-up to \"Infinity War\" and \"Endgame.\"\n\nMaybe Marvel will never reach those heights again. Most of the stars that got them there have left the franchise, and working in this system is clearly taxing. Maybe the Russo Bros. will return and save the day for the next two Avengers movies as is being reported. Whatever the case, I just got to see two characters I never expected in the MCU.\n\nTo pharaphrase Wade Wilson, I've been waiting a long time for this team-up. And it was worth the wait.\n\n* 'Quantumania' is proof. We can officially panic about Marvel. | Review\n\n* 'Wakanda Forever' doesn't touch 'Black Panther.' It never could. | Review\n\n* Does the biggest scene in 2021's biggest movie take place in N.J.? You're welcome, Spider-Man!\n\n* 'Avengers: Infinity War' review: Epic action fuels a controversial finish (NO SPOILERS)\n\n* 'Avengers: Endgame' made me cry like a freaking toddler. Here's why.", "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NJ.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jeremy_schneider@nj.com", "name": "Jeremy Schneider", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Avengers (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadpool_(video_game)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Deadpool (video game)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolverine", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Wolverine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Marvel Cinematic Universe"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comic_book", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Comic book"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Comics", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label":
