{"uri": "2024-07-433495342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:39:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:39:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:28:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/25/movies/deadpool-wolverine-movie-reviews.html", "title": "'Deadpool & Wolverine' Reviews Are In: Amusing or Exhausting?", "body": "Few critics could deny that the highly anticipated super spectacle, starring Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, has its charms -- but most left wanting more.\n\nAfter a summer without superheroes, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is slashing its way into theaters.\n\nThe high-octane collision of the wisecracking antihero Deadpool, played by Ryan Reynolds in two previous films, and the hulking and messianic Wolverine, played by Hugh Jackman (returning to the role for the first time since \"Logan\" in 2017), marks Marvel Studios' only release of the calendar year. The movie, directed by Shawn Levy, is projected to have the best ever domestic opening weekend for an R-rated film.\n\nMost critics have found something to like in \"Deadpool & Wolverine,\" which has an 81 percent fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes. They say it has a superpowered jokes-per-minute ratio and two winning performances from its lead actors. But many reviewers had a mixed-to-negative assessment of the movie overall, calling it difficult to follow, lacking in real tension or stakes and overly reliant on self-referential story lines.\n\nRead on for some highlights.\n\nLook, I Laughed [Vulture]\n\nThe movie's aggressive sense of humor about itself may win you over despite its flaws. \"'Deadpool & Wolverine' isn't a particularly good movie -- I'm not even sure it is a movie,\" Bilge Ebiri wrote. \"But it's so determined to beat you down with its incessant irreverence that you might find yourself submitting to it.\"\n\nNothing Ever Ends [The New York Times]\n\nThe movie's existence reflects Hollywood's inability to \"let well enough alone,\" wrote Alissa Wilkinson, but it's entertaining nonetheless. \"It still features Reynolds making fun of himself; it has some fun set pieces, clever sight gags, amusing surprises, left-field references and adoring pauses to admire Jackman's biceps and abs.\"\n\n'Deadpool & Wolverine' Makes the M.C.U. the Villain -- and Not in a Good Way [Polygon]\n\nIn a negative review, Joshua Rivera found the film dispiritingly hollow. \"'Deadpool & Wolverine' has made its hero the worst kind of comic book character: one who doesn't stand for anything.\"\n\nRyan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman's Sarky Gagathon Mocks the M.C.U. Back to Life [The Guardian]\n\nPeter Bradshaw appreciated the movie's satirical bent while capturing a common complaint about it in a few words. \"It's amusing and exhausting,\" he wrote.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-433694996", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:36:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:36:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:36:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/business/money-report/deadpool-and-wolverine-set-for-highest-opening-of-an-r-rated-film/3603183/", "title": "'Deadpool & Wolverine' set for highest opening of an R-rated film", "body": "The \"Merc with a Mouth\" returns to the big screen this weekend, and he is doing more than bringing an R-rating to Disney's Marvel Cinematic Universe.\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine,\" the third stand-alone feature starring Ryan Reynolds as the regenerating degenerate, is expected to tally between $160 million and $180 million at the domestic box office during its debut.\n\nThe film is already the best ticket preseller of 2024, according to Fandango, and it is set to break numerous records during its opening weekend. Those marks include the highest domestic opening of 2024 and the biggest debut ever for an R-rated film.\n\nDisney and Pixar's \"Inside Out 2\" is currently the highest opener of the year at $154.2 million and the first \"Deadpool\" film's $132.4 million debut is the highest for any R-rated feature, according to data from Comscore.\n\n\"I think no question this is going to open as the largest R-rated movie of all time,\" said Mike Bowers, president and CEO of Harkins Theatres, a theater chain based in Arizona. \"And it's already one of the top presale movies historically for us.\"\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is the 34th film to be released under the MCU banner and the first to garner an R-rating from the Motion Picture Association. The previous two Deadpool films, both rated R, were produced and released through 20th Century Fox. Disney acquired the company in 2019, bringing the X-Men and Fantastic Four back into the larger Marvel portfolio.\n\nSimilar to previous entries in the MCU, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is benefiting from fan fervor. Audiences are eager to see the flick in its opening weekend in order to avoid spoilers. Disney has kept much of the film's content secret and provided limited press screenings prior to its debut.\n\nBowers expects audiences will keep coming back for more in the weeks after the film's opening.\n\n\"This is a film that there's so much happening, so many jokes and funny sequences that no one's gonna be able to eat just one, you know, they're gonna be back,\" he said.\n\nEllis Jacob, president and CEO of Cineplex, the largest movie theater chain in Canada, echoed Bower's thoughts. Jacob said \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is filled with Easter eggs and audiences will return to try and see them all.\n\nHe also noted that many of those moviegoers are buying tickets for premium screenings, such as IMAX, Dolby and ScreenX, which come at higher prices.\n\nMarvel has also collaborated with movie theaters to license merchandise such as collectible popcorn buckets and drink containers that cinema operators expect will sell quickly. Concessions have always been the biggest money maker for theaters, and having limited-edition items can drive even higher food and beverage sales.\n\nOf course, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is also an important release for the overall Marvel Cinematic Universe. Disney has \"eased off the gas pedal\" and planned fewer releases in the series that drove the global box office for more than a decade, said Shawn Robbins, founder and owner of Box Office Theory. He said Disney is trying to right the ship after a series of theatrical missteps and poor box office hauls, as well as a deluge of streaming content that overcrowded the market and overwhelmed even the MCU's biggest fans.\n\n\"Ultimately, as much as this is a Marvel movie, it may be viewed equally as a midsummer action comedy that stars personalities and brands that die-hard fans and casual viewers love,\" said Robbins. \"Reynolds and Jackman are a grand slam duo given their respective pop culture presences and friendly back-and-forth across social media and interviews. There's also a genuine curiosity about how the MCU's first R-rated film will play out and hold to the qualities which made the first two Deadpool films and [Jackman's 2017 Wolverine film] 'Logan' so popular.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcbayarea.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Bay Area"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_whitten@nbcbayarea.com", "name": "Sarah Whitten", "type": "author", {"uri": "8243381753", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:19:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:19:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:18:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://comicbookmovie.com/deadpool/deadpool-wolverine/deadpool-wolverine-drops-some-intriguing-hints-about-the-titular-duos-mcu-future---spoilers-a212305", "title": "DEADPOOL & WOLVERINE Drops Some Intriguing Hints About The Titular Duo's MCU Future - SPOILERS", "body": "Like many of you, we'd expected Deadpool & Wolverine to be a two-hour commercial for Avengers 5. Instead, it's a phenomenal standalone adventure which, despite some exciting nods to the wider MCU, keeps the focus on its leads.\n\nStill, there are some intriguing hints about what the future holds in store for Wade Wilson and Logan in the MCU.\n\nWhen Mr. Paradox first brings the Merc with the Mouth to the TVA, he offers him a place on the Sacred Timeline (Earth-616) before Earth-100005's destruction. However, he only does so because his bosses believe the anti-hero has an important role to play in the future.\n\nDeadpool even gets a glimpse of that when we see a screen with Chris Hemsworth's Thor cradling a dying Wade (half his mask has been destroyed) as he sobs over his fallen comrade. It might be a gag, but Paradox really doesn't want the Merc to see his future so this scene may well be revisited.\n\nAs we explained earlier today, Deadpool & Wolverine concludes with the title duo back on Earth-100005 as the timeline thrives. Loki's Hunter B-15 arrests Paradox for his creation of the Time Ripper and says to Wade and Logan that their role in the Multiverse is just beginning. Once again, the insinuation is that these two are crucial to what's happening on the Sacred Timeline.\n\nHowever, if Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman decline to return, this movie still serves as a fitting and emotional send-off.\n\nDeadpool can work in a PG-13 setting (albeit sparingly) and it's established earlier in the movie that Wolverine is no fan of Earth's Mightiest Heroes when he says, \"F*** The Avengers.\" With that in mind, Avengers 5 and Avengers: Secret Wars must be something the actors have discussed with Kevin Feige.\n\nWill these two find themselves on opposite sides of a conflict between the Avengers and X-Men? That would be a fun way to give us a rematch...\n\nYou can read our full review of Deadpool & Wolverine here, but we concluded by saying, \"A contender for the best superhero movie ever, Deadpool & Wolverine is two hours of Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman proving they were born to play these roles and, crucially, be part of the MCU. It's a f***ing masterpiece.\"\n\nShawn Levy directs Deadpool & Wolverine, which stars Ryan Reynolds, Hugh Jackman, Emma Corrin, Morena Baccarin, Rob Delaney, Leslie Uggams, Karan Soni, Matthew Macfadyen, and Dafne Keen. The movie is written by Ryan Reynolds & Rhett Reese & Paul Wernick & Zeb Wells & Shawn Levy.\n\nKevin Feige, Reynolds, Levy and Lauren Shuler Donner produce with Louis D'Esposito, Wendy Jacobson, Mary McLaglen, Josh McLaglen, Rhett Reese, Paul Wernick, George Dewey, Simon Kinberg and Jonathon Komack Martin serving as executive producers.", "source": {"uri": "comicbookmovie.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243740586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:02:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:02:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:01:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.slashfilm.com/1630394/deadpool-and-wolverine-ending-explained/", "title": "Deadpool & Wolverine Ending Explained: What's Next For Wade & Logan? - SlashFilm", "body": "Warning: This ending explainer contains major spoilers for \"Deadpool & Wolverine.\" Read at your own risk.\n\nWhat's next for Wade & Logan, you ask? Well, it depends on which Wade & Logan we're talking about.\n\nThe issue with that question, and one of the major issues with \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" (if not the entire Multiverse Saga) is one of variants. When the Marvel Cinematic Universe began back in the merry days of 2008, a post-credits tease at the end of Jon Favreau's \"Iron Man\" promised more Marvel characters would make it to the big screen and share space. As this shot-calling prophecy came to pass, it wasn't just a fulfillment of the pipe dreams of so many comic book lovers; it was also a promise that these characters would be done the \"right\" way.\n\nThat's because, until the MCU began, Marvel characters on screen had been handled by other studios -- namely Sony and 20th Century Fox -- who dared to reconceptualize certain canonic aspects of these heroes. As the more \"accurate\" MCU grew to heights of rabid popularity, the Sony and Fox-produced Marvel films (which were once the only game in town) now seemed odd and almost quaint. They were the kooky underdogs, after a fashion, and it's in that spirit that 2016's \"Deadpool\" and its sequel, 2018's \"Deadpool 2,\" felt genuinely subversive. Those films had no need to assuage MCU management; they could throw up a middle finger at themselves, other comic book films, and geek culture with abandon.\n\nNow, with \"Deadpool & Wolverine,\" we have a movie that's ostensibly a swan song for the Fox-verse which also welcomes the two titular un-killable mutants to the MCU. Yet this film canonically does not feature the same old Wolverine, and, in essence, the old Deadpool is gone, too.", "source": {"uri": "slashfilm.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Slashfilm"}, After making his debut as The Merc with a Mouth in X-Men Origins: Wolverine in 2009, Reynolds knew that one day he wanted to make his Deadpool-Wolverine team-up official once more on the big screen. He even asked Marvel Studios President Kevin Feige about it when Disney acquired Fox - the then-studio behind both characters - in 2019.\n\n\"I've waited my whole life to work with him in this way,\" he tells Complex. \"The opportunity to do something just slightly new with [Wolverine] in this movie was really special,\" Reynolds adds.\n\nJackman, synonymous with Wolverine for over two decades and who fans thought they had seen the last of after his death in Logan (2017), brings a new level of enthusiasm to this project, largely fueled by a long-overdue costume change with his debut in the comic-accurate yellow suit. \"I looked in the mirror and was like, 'Damn, how the hell did I not do this for the last 24 years?\" Jackman comments with a chuckle.\n\nThis film not only brings these two powerhouse actors together, but also marks a new chapter for the duo as they transition from the Fox era to Disney's Marvel Cinematic Universe, an exciting new playground with endless possibilities. The merger has opened up a treasure trove of possibilities, and Reynolds and Jackman hold no stops exploring this new playground in their upcoming movie.\n\nAs Deadpool & Wolverine prepares to hit theaters, the excitement surrounding this Marvel debut is palpable. While \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" has certainly made a splash with an 85% on Rotten Tomatoes, it's a bit of a letdown compared to its predecessors.\n\nThe original film and its sequel both boasted higher scores, setting the bar incredibly high for this latest film. While it's still a fun ride, fans might be left wanting a little more from the Merc with a Mouth and his clawed counterpart. This score indicates a critical success and bodes well for the movie's box office performance.\n\nThe film reunites Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, reprising their iconic roles of Deadpool and Wolverine, respectively. Fans have been eagerly awaiting this team-up since the success of the first two Deadpool movies.\n\nEarly reviews point to a successful blend of action, humor, and character development.\n\n\"Deadpool & wolverine retains all the edge of Deadpool's Fox projects but with enough Disney budget to make his exploits feel bigger and crazier than ever,\" noted reviewer Christopher Campbell at Tom's Guide.\n\nWith a positive critical reception and a loyal fanbase, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" looks poised to be a summer blockbuster. {"uri": "2024-07-433696888", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:39:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:39:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:37:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://venturebeat.com/games/deadpool-and-wolverine-movie-marketing-blitz-hits-video-games/", "title": "Deadpool and Wolverine movie marketing blitz hits video games", "body": "GamesBeat is excited to partner with Lil Snack to have customized games just for our audience! We know as gamers ourselves, this is an exciting way to engage through play with the GamesBeat content you have already come to love. Start playing games here.\n\nDeadpool and Wolverine is one of the most anticipated movies of the year, thanks in part to its clever (and widespread) marketing blitz. In addition to a wide variety of brands, the third Deadpool outing (and his first in the Marvel Cinematic Universe) is leveraging video game partnerships to promote the film to players.\n\nFrom its viral cheeky controllers to in-game takeovers, the gaming activations promoting Deadpool and Wolverine broadly fall into two categories: crossovers with other gaming properties and games based on Marvel IP.\n\nNotably, two major titles are missing on this list -- Marvel Rivals and Call of Duty. NetEase is currently running its closed beta test for its team-based hero shooter Marvel Rivals. While the company is attending San Diego Comic Con, the team hasn't cross-promoted Deadpool and Wolverine yet.\n\nMeanwhile, fans theorized that Call of Duty would also run a promotional event for the film. However, the data mined animations fans used as evidence turned out to be for its current WWE crossover.\n\nMarvel Snap, the mobile collectible card game from Second Dinner and Nuverse, has themed its current competitive season around Deadpool. Dubbed Maximum Effort, the season pass features themed cosmetics and the introduction of Gwenpool as a card. Additionally, the season added two new themed locations -- Weapon X Facility and Taco Truck -- to its rotation.\n\nThe game also rolled out a new time-limited mode called Deadpool's Diner. Players can climb the ranks and earn up to 32 different rewards in the high-risk, high-reward mode. These include themed cosmetics and the new Cassandra Nova card -- the villain of the Deadpool and Wolverine movie.\n\nTo fully promote this limited time mode, Marvel Snap has organized a creator tournament on July 26. In the Conquerors Deadpool Domination tournament, 14 creators will play Deadpool's Diner starting at 12 p.m. PT to collect as many 'bubs' as they can. The creator with the most after two hours will take home the crown. Players can vote for who they think will win for additional in-game currency and the chance at an exclusive Elektra card variant.\n\nMarvel Snap also ran a Twitch Drops campaign themed around the upcoming movie. Players that linked their in-game and Twitch accounts and watched for six hours could earn a new Wolverine card variant.\n\nMarvel Strike Force\n\nBeat the heat in Marvel Strike Force's Deadpool and Wolverine-themed pool party event. In this four-week long adventure, players will follow Deadpool as he turns S.H.I.E.L.D.'s Hellicarrier into a summer pool party. Each week, gamers can play four new missions for Scopely's turn-based mobile RPG.\n\nOf course, this event comes with plenty of cosmetics for players to earn. Its major milestones include two Wolverine skins and \"Deadpool's Super Secret Costume.\"\n\nMarvel: Conquest of Champions\n\nThis 2014 mobile fighting game from Kabam had a minor event to celebrate the release of Deadpool and Wolverine. In May, the game also welcomed a fan favorite from the Deadpool movies to its roster: Teenage Negasonic Warhead.\n\nMarvel Puzzle Quest\n\nFans of 505 Games' 2013 mobile puzzle game can enter this giveaway for their chance to earn movie ticket and Deadpool and Wolverine-themed in-game rewards. The five grand prize winners will receive a $100 movie theater digital gift card.\n\nMarvel Studios Deadpool and Wolverine hits theaters this Friday, July 26.", "source": {"uri": "venturebeat.com", lashings of gore", "body": "Odd couple movies usually generate their fair share of bickering and mutual animosity, but when the odd couple are Deadpool & Wolverine (16s), the enmity quickly takes on a lethal quality, despite both heroes being essentially unkillable.\n\nHaving discovered that the Time Variance Authority (TVA) plans to wipe out his universe to preserve 'the sacred timeline', Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) finds himself obliged to resurrect his old nemesis Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) to do battle with the TVA's Mr Paradox (Matthew Macfadyen) and Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrin), the fearsome queen who rules over the Void where unwanted and outdated superheroes are dispatched to live a purgatorial existence.\n\nAll of which, of course, is merely an excuse to unleash the anti-superhero Deadpool and his knowing, sarky commentary on the excesses of the superhero genre, and in this the movie doesn't disappoint, with Deadpool, the self-proclaimed 'Marvel Jesus' appointed to save the multiverse from itself, in scabrous form once more.\n\nEasily the most irreverent superhero movie to date, the story - co-written by Reynolds, Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick, with Shawn Levy directing - pushes too hard against the fourth wall at times, and can feel smugly self-congratulatory.\n\nThat said, if you're a fan of inventive carnage and lashings of gore, Deadpool & Wolverine delivers in spades.\n\nHugh Jackman is good value as the grizzled Wolverine (or a version of same), Ryan Reynolds is irrepressible as the foul-mouthed Deadpool, and there's a whole host of cameos filling out the Don't @ me.\n\nIf there's one thing you can be sure of when you go to see a Marvel movie -- really any action movie these days -- it's the presence of a post-credits scene and Deadpool & Wolverine is no exception. The third film in the Deadpool franchise hit cinemas on July 26, 2024, but the hype began well and truly before then.\n\nRelated: Here are all the biggest Deadpool & Wolverine spoilers to read at your own peril\n\nThe MCU has a rich history of post-credits scenes, ranging from teasers for future films to entertaining silliness. As of Echo (2024), there have been more than 81 post-credits scenes across 45 properties, including films, short films, television series, animated shorts, and television specials.\n\nIf you're seeing a Marvel film in the theater, there's no question you're hanging around until the end when the lights come on. Post-credits scenes are perhaps the most anticipated part of any Marvel movie -- in fact, in 2021's Eternals, one journalist spoiled the fact that Harry Styles makes a cameo appearance and faced the wrath of fans online for ruining the moment. With its latest installment, here's everything you need to know about the Deadpool & Wolverine post-credits scene. Spoilers ahead!\n\nHow many post-credit scenes are there?\n\nThere's one post-credits scene in Deadpool & Wolverine and it happens right at the end. However, there are other tributes to 20th Century Fox (Marvel's former owner) throughout the mid-credits set to Green Day's classic song Good Riddance (Time of Your Life).\n\nTo explain the context of the post-credits scene: earlier in the film, Deadpool tells villain Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrin) that Johnny Storm (Chris Evans) has been talking shit about her, including how he'd rather die by her hands than work for her.\n\nWe're led to believe Deadpool made it all up, that Johnny didn't say all of those things, so when Nova kills Johnny, the audience is supposed to be shocked because we think he died in vain. Come to the post-credits, Deadpool addresses the audience, explaining that he didn't want us to think he was responsible for Johnny's death.\n\nWe're shown footage wherein Johnny says, verbatim, what Deadpool said he did, including that Cassandra can \"lick my god damn cinnamon ring clean,\" says Evans. \"I won't be happy until I've urinated on her freshly-barbecued corpse.\" LOL", "source": Before the film's release here is a recap of what you need to remember.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by @deadpoolmovie\n\nAfter being diagnosed with terminal cancer, Wade is approached by a secret program that promises to cure his cancer and grant him superhuman abilities. However, the experimentation includes injecting him with a serum designed to awaken latent mutant genes. But the only way to awaken it is by extreme stress and near-death experiences. After being burned to death in an explosion, Wade attains regenerative healing power that cures his cancer and gives him the ability to heal from any injury rapidly.\n\nDeadpool 2 ending changed the timeline. Cable gifted his time travel device as a token of appreciation for helping him save his family. It has led to him travelling through time over and over again to save Vanessa from being killed by a hitman. Deadpool 3 teaser also confirmed that Wade went back to save various members of X-Force who had met untimely deaths. Deadpool can be seen calling them his family that he needs to protect and save once again.\n\nSEE ALSO: Deadpool & Wolverine: From Vanessa, Sabertooth To Possible Ladypool, Every Cameo Explained\n\nWade's constant trips through time and messing with timelines has seems to be what led the TVA to him, which will eventually land him in the void. The void is also the same place where pruned variants end up. Loki shows different variants of Loki stuck there, as we might also see different versions of X-men and Deadpool, which were caught and pruned by the TVA.\n\nMeanwhile, TVA has gone through a major change in recent releases. Loki has not only saved the multiverse, but TVA is now working to protect the timeline. Loki saving the multiverse could mean that Fox century's X-Men universe could have been one of the many branching timelines which has now been preserved. And with Loki changing the objective of the TVA (which is now to save all the branched timeline) we could see how they aim to help Wolverine save his timeline as well.\n\nAmid all the different branches of the timeline, one still exists when Deadpool and Wolverine originally met in X-Men Origins: Wolverine. Wade Wilson has previously mentioned the same in Deadpool 2, however, it is likely that the same will come up again. Deadpool in the original film though played by Ryan Reynolds looked very different. Instead of knives, he was given a singular sword length claw on each hand to fight. Other controversial changes to his character include laser eyes and sewing his mouth shut.\n\nSEE ALSO: Agatha All Along Trailer Breakdown: New Characters, Easter Eggs And Secrets You Missed\n\nWolverine once again met Deadpool from the current MCU universe when he travelled between the worlds to kill that version of himself. However, it is unclear if the Logan we meet in Deadpool & Wolverine will be the same one from X-Men Origins: Wolverine. For the unversed, Hugh Jackman's character has seen and changed several timelines himself. While he died in the 2017 film Logan, there is another timeline which was saved at the end of Days of Future Past. Meanwhile, the timelines in Deadpool & Wolverine shows a world were all the other X-men have died. Some of these timelines maybe connected but can be confirmed only after the film releases.\n\nThe biggest concern for TVA and in turn Logan and Wade Wilson will be MCU grappling with \"Incursion\" events as shown in Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness. Loki's work may have slowed down the process but it hasn't stopped from universes collide and spill into one another. {"uri": "8243148998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:36:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:36:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:35:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.gamesradar.com/entertainment/marvel-movies/deadpool-and-wolverine-one-blade-joke-fans-love-marvel-mcu/", "title": "Marvel fans are loving one of Deadpool and Wolverine's cheekiest moments", "body": "Deadpool and Wolverine has some seriously meta gags, and fans are loving one in particular\n\nDeadpool and Wolverine features its fair share of meta gags, and there's one in particular that Marvel fans are loving.\n\nNow, before we go any further, this is your warning that the following contains major spoilers for Deadpool and Wolverine! Turn back now if you haven't seen the Marvel Phase 5 movie yet!\n\nNow, if you're still reading, then you'll know that one of the Deadpool and Wolverine cameos is Wesley Snipes as Blade. He helps Wade and Logan make it back to Cassandra Nova's lair, in the hopes that they can break free and get home to Earth-616.\n\nAs the group, which also includes Jennifer Garner as Elektra, Channing Tatum as Gambit, and Dafne Keen as X-23, races towards Cassandra, a reference is made to Punisher. Deadpool asks which Punisher they're talking about, as there have been more than one. Snipes then says there is only one Blade - and there's only going to be one Blade. Cue Deadpool looking straight down the camera.\n\nOf course, the MCU is attempting to reboot Blade with a new movie starring Mahershala Ali. The key word there, though, is attempting. The new film has been plagued by production setbacks, meaning that, five years after it was announced, we're still no closer to the film hitting the big screen. Snipes himself even poked fun at the most recent behind the scenes upheaval.\n\n\"Best line of the movie good god,\" says one fan, while another says: \"When Snipes says there's only one Blade, and Deadpool looks at the camera all smug, I cried out in laughter. What a perfect movie to say goodbye to Fox, they got away with so many jokes because they could outright say it.\"\n\n\"What's great about Snipes' Blade quote is that Deadpool's stare at the camera can be interpreted in many ways. It's either: 'This dude doesn't know Marvel Studios is recasting the character for a solo film,' 'This dude is right. That Blade Marvel Studios film is never happening LMAO' And an extra: 'This dude doesn't know about the super obscure Blade TV Show,'\" says someone else. In Blade: The Series, Kirk Jones played the character.\n\nDeadpool and Wolverine is in UK cinemas now and hits US theaters on July 26. For more on the movie, check out our piece on the Deadpool and Wolverine post-credits scene or our verdict on the film in our Deadpool and Wolverine review.\n\nAs for what Marvel has in store for us next, see our guide to all the upcoming Marvel movies and shows, or get ready with our how-to on watching the Marvel movies in order.", "source": {"uri": "gamesradar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-433787051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:02:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:02:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:51:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.vulture.com/article/deadpool-wolverine-cameos-marvel-mcu-fox.html", "title": "The Cameos Are the Best Part of Deadpool & Wolverine", "body": "You might go into Deadpool & Wolverine expecting to see familiar faces from comic-book movies past, but the sheer specificity of its many, many cameos may still take you by surprise. Between a story that involves Marvel's \"multiverse\" and the merc-with-the-mouth's proclivity for fourth-wall breaking, the Deadpool threequel is practically tailor-made for special appearances.\n\nThese cameos include existing Marvel characters, several who starred in pre-MCU movies from other studios, and even casting rumors that will only make sense if you're attuned to comic-book movie production news (\u00e0 la Nicolas Cage's Superman in The Flash). While their sheer variety borders on gratuitous, they also happen to lead several genuinely hilarious and meaningful moments. And since the movie is scant on coherent drama for its leads (and cuts away quickly the moment its action threatens to become cool), these surprise appearances may just be the best part of Deadpool & Wolverine, whether they're in-jokes for the fans, or serve an actual purpose in the plot -- or in some cases, both.\n\nJon Favreau as Happy Hogan\n\nThe first cameo is a low-key one: Jon Favreau's Happy Hogan, friend and security chief to the unseen Tony Stark. This scene, set in the main Marvel universe six years in the past (while Stark was still alive), sees Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) sitting down for a job interview to become an Avenger. He gets rejected, a blow to his self-worth that ripples throughout the movie. As an everyday human with no superpowers, Happy may not be the MCU's most glamorous character, but he's been part of the franchise since the beginning (Favreau both appeared in and directed the original Iron Man), and his presence is a fitting way to welcome Deadpool into the Marvel fold.\n\nChris Hemsworth as Thor\n\nYears later, once Deadpool ends up in trouble with the Time Variance Authority (the time-keeping organization from Loki), hints that we're now in the MCU start popping up onscreen. We see scenes from The Avengers, and one in which Thor (Chris Hemsworth) weeps over Deadpool's dying body. That may not technically count as a new appearance, since the image recycles and manipulates existing footage (Hemsworth wasn't even aware he was in Deadpool & Wolverine), but there's no dearth of traditional cameos in the rest of the film.\n\nThe (back of) Hulk('s head)\n\nAs Deadpool travels across the multiverse in search of different versions of Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), he comes across one who happens to be fighting the Hulk, whom we see from behind. It's a nice reference to Wolverine's first-ever comic appearance, in which he battles the big green Avenger.\n\nHenry Cavill as Wolverine\n\nHere's where things start to get weird. Deadpool finds a version of Wolverine played by none other than former Superman actor Henry Cavill. Like John Krasinski's Reed Richards in the Doctor Strange sequel, Cavill's appearance pays off years of fan art and online chatter about who should take over from Jackman when he eventually passes the torch, though given how much money Deadpool & Wolverine is about to make, that might not happen anytime soon.\n\nTyler Mane as Sabretooth and more X-Men baddies\n\nOnce Deadpool begins multiverse-hopping -- and especially once he and Wolverine get stuck in \"the void,\" where characters and elements from alternate realities are sent to die -- all bets are off. Nobody really needs a concrete reason to show up beyond the filmmakers deciding they should, so we get a few appearances from X-Men actors and characters of old. Tyler Mane reprises his role as the feral Sabretooth from X-Men (2000), and he's joined by the fire-wielding Pyro (Aaron Stanford) from X2: X-Men United (2003) and X-Men: The Last Stand (2006). They belong to a band of wasteland outlaws populated by other Marvel villains from 20th Century Fox films, albeit played by new actors since they happen to be \"variants.\" These include Toad from X-Men, Lady Deathstrike from X2, Juggernaut, Callisto, and Arclight from The Last Stand, Azazel from X-Men First Class, Psylocke from X-Men: Apocalypse, Bullseye from Daredevil, and even \"The Russian\" from Lionsgate's 2004 version of The Punisher.\n\nChris Evans as Johnny Storm\n\nBut the first hero from a pre-MCU Marvel movie arrives in the form of a major bait and switch. A hooded figure in blue speaks in a familiar voice and reveals himself to be played by Marvel mainstay Chris Evans. As Alan Silvestri's Avengers theme fades in on the soundtrack, Deadpool excitedly prepares for Captain America to utter his iconic rallying call: \"Avengers assemble!\" Except, at the last second, Evans instead yells, \"Flame on!\" Turns out Evans is reprising his second-most-famous comic-book role, the Human Torch, a.k.a. Johnny Storm from Fox's Fantastic Four (2005), who takes to the sky in a literal blaze of glory.\n\nDafne Keen as X-23\n\nThis sets the stage for several other Marvel characters from Fox movies to appear. As teased in a recent trailer, a now adult Dafne Keen reprises her role as Laura/X-23 from Logan (2017) to give Wolverine a pep talk, which is sweet, even though this version of Wolverine has never met her before. She's part of a group whose worlds have all been destroyed and who are now looking for ways to finish their stories -- a nice meta-reference to some of their franchises being cut short or never getting off the ground to begin with.\n\nJennifer Garner as Elektra\n\nThe first of these characters to appear is Jennifer Garner's sai-wielding anti-hero Elektra Natchios, from Fox's much-maligned Daredevil (2003) and Elektra (2005). Garner's version of the character (who has since been played by Elodie Yung on Netflix) isn't particularly well regarded by fans, but the character's poor reception plays into her story here as someone searching for absolution and a way to bring her story to fruition. Plus, Garner's specific presence also yields a fun jab at ex-husband Ben Affleck, whose Daredevil is said to have died off-screen. When Deadpool offers his condolences, she quickly brushes it off with a snappy, \"It's fine.\"\n\nWesley Snipes as Blade\n\nGarner's older, wiser Elektra is followed by a similarly aged-up Blade, the day-walking vampire (and vampire hunter) played by Wesley Snipes in New Line's Blade trilogy. The actor's graying beard adds to his panache -- few superheroes have ever looked as cool in the genre's history -- but his appearance is especially surprising. Snipes famously hated working with Reynolds on Blade: Trinity, behind-the-scenes lore this film makes sure to reference. Before he heads off to battle, Snipes quips that there's only one Blade, and there's only going to be one Blade, a clear jab at Marvel's reboot of the character starring Mahershala Ali, which was first announced in 2019 but has since languished in production limbo.\n\nChanning Tatum as Gambit\n\nAnd finally, Channing Tatum shows up as a surprisingly comics-accurate version of Remy LeBeau/Gambit, the character he signed on to play in an X-Men spinoff back in 2014, which was eventually shelved amid the Fox-Disney merger five years later. Tatum is perhaps the funniest part of the entire film and actually makes the case for why his solo project being canceled may have been a good thing: His attempt at the character's Cajun accent is completely (and intentionally) incomprehensible.\n\nWunmi Mosaku as Hunter B-15, Blake Lively as Lady Deadpool, and more cameos\n\nThe above are all the movie's biggest cameos, but there are more familiar faces almost everywhere you look. Wunmi Mosaku briefly reprises her role as TVA agent Hunter B-15 from Loki, while a female version of Deadpool, long rumored to be played by Taylor Swift, is played by Reynolds's wife, Blake Lively -- or at least voiced by her (we never see her face). And, of course, it wouldn't be a Marvel movie without the late Stan Lee, whose face can be seen in an advertisement on the side of a bus.", "source": {"uri": "vulture.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-433742489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:01:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://me.mashable.com/entertainment/44558/deadpool-wolverine-chris-evans-returns-to-the-mcu-but-not-as-captain-america", "title": "'Deadpool & Wolverine': Chris Evans returns to the MCU but not as Captain America", "body": "***Spoilers ahead***\n\nMarvel admitted they fake planted leaks to hide the biggest cameos of 'Deadpool & Wolverine' and their well-plotted scheme worked just fine. Chris Evans, the beloved Captain America, who retired from his post after the events of 'Avengers: Endgame', makes a comeback in this Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman-led film in an unexpected special appearance that fans could never guess.\n\nTo understand his comeback, we must turn back the time to 2005, when Evans first played Johnny Storm in 20th Century Fox's original production Fantastic Four, later acquired by Disney. Almost five years before he appeared as Steve Rogers in the MCU, Evans played The Human Torch, who was revived in the latest entry of Deadpool.\n\nJohnny Storm meets Reynolds' The Merc With The Mouth and Jackman's clawed mutant in the Void dimension, a purgatory reality of sorts, where the TVA (Time Variance Authority) punishes revolting superheroes. This Johnny is all talks and no flames, consistent with the humorous plot of the film. He serves as the bridge to Deadpool and Wolverine meeting the main villain Cassandra Nova and a funny one at that.\n\nEvans' cameo culminates amusingly with Deadpool quipping a Disney-can't-afford-him joke, evoking laughter. Notably, his appearance is another theatrical gimmick of Marvel with potentially no future as we all know it is Stranger Things fame Joseph Quinn who takes on the role of Johnny Storm in MCU's revival of Fantastic Four, scheduled to release in 2025.\n\nBesides Chris Evans, Henry Cavill as Wolverine is another unexpected cameo in 'Deadpool & Wolverine' along with many X-Men Mutants Elektra, Gambit, and more. {"uri": "8243402120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:34:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:34:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:33:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/25/deadpool-and-wolverine-set-for-highest-opening-of-an-r-rated-film.html", "title": "'Deadpool and Wolverine' set for highest opening of an R-rated film", "body": "\"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is the 34th film to be released under the MCU banner and the first to garner an R-rating from the Motion Picture Association. The previous two Deadpool films, both rated R, were produced and released through 20th Century Fox. Disney acquired the company in 2019, bringing the X-Men and Fantastic Four back into the larger Marvel portfolio.\n\nLike previous entries in the MCU, \"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is benefitting from fan fervor. Audiences are eager to see the flick in its opening weekend in order to avoid spoilers. Disney has kept much of the film's content secret and provided limited press screenings prior to its debut.\n\nAnd Bowers expects audiences will keep coming back for more in the weeks after the film's opening.\n\n\"This is a film that there's so much happening, so many jokes and funny sequences that no one's gonna be able to eat just one, you know, they're gonna be back,\" he said.\n\nEllis Jacob, president and CEO of Cineplex, the largest movie theater chain in Canada, echoed Bower's thoughts. Jacob said \"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is filled with Easter eggs and audiences will return to try and see them all.\n\nHe also noted that many of those moviegoers are buying tickets for premium screenings, like IMAX, Dolby and ScreenX, which come at higher prices.\n\nMarvel has also collaborated with movie theaters to license merchandise like collectible popcorn buckets and drink containers that cinema operators expect will sell quickly. Concessions have always been the biggest money maker for theaters, and having limited edition items can drive even higher food and beverage sales.\n\nOf course, \"Deadpool and Wolverine\" is also an important release for the overall Marvel Cinematic Universe. Disney has \"eased off the gas pedal\" and planned fewer releases in the series that drove the global box office for more than a decade, said Shawn Robbins, founder and owner of Box Office Theory. He said Disney is trying to right the ship after a series of theatrical missteps and poor box office hauls, as well as an deluge of streaming content that overcrowded the market and overwhelmed even the MCU's biggest fans.\n\n\"Ultimately, as much as this is a Marvel movie, it may be viewed equally as a midsummer action comedy that stars personalities and brands that die-hard fans and casual viewers love,\" said Robbins. \"Reynolds and Jackman are a grand slam duo given their respective pop culture presences and friendly back-and-forth across social media and interviews. There's also a genuine curiosity about how the MCU's first R-rated film will play out and hold to the qualities which made the first two Deadpool films and [Jackman's 2017 Wolverine film] 'Logan' so popular.\"", "source": {"uri": "cnbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNBC"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_whitten@cnbc.com", "name": "Sarah Whitten", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], {"uri": "2024-07-433703798", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:48:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:48:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:48:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://people.com/deadpool-and-wolverine-parents-guide-8683026", "title": "Is Deadpool & Wolverine OK for Kids? What Parents Should Know About the R-Rated Marvel Sequel", "body": "Benjamin VanHoose is an Associate Editor on the Movies team at PEOPLE. He has written about entertainment and breaking news for over five years.\n\nDeadpool's raunchy humor is now officially part of Disney's Marvel Cinematic Universe.\n\nRyan Reynolds brings the comic book character's vulgar sensibilities to the world of the Avengers in Deadpool & Wolverine, which comes after Disney purchased Fox, which oversaw the previous Deadpool and X-Men films.\n\nThe film, which also stars Hugh Jackman as Wolverine, is rated R for \"strong bloody violence and language throughout, gore and sexual references.\" Before it, the last two Deadpool films, which hit theaters in 2016 and 2018, were also rated R.\n\nVariety asked director Shawn Levy as well as Reynolds and Jackman if they thought the film is suitable for kids.\n\n\"It's obviously R-rated, and I don't want to get in trouble by encouraging -- ,\" began Levy, as Reynolds said, \"I do. So many kids have seen Deadpool and Deadpool 2. My own kids have seen it. ... It's never rated R just to be rated R. A lot of it is just the character. The character is very crass. His brain is like a half-eaten omelet inside the skull of a 7-year-old.\"\n\nSaid Jackman, \"I'm going to be responsible here. Don't bring a 2-year-old,\" and Levy joked, \"Okay, fine. We draw the line at 3.\" Reynolds further quipped, \"Don't bring a 114-year-old, because that person will not leave alive. Anyone in a diaper.\"\n\nRead on for what parents should know before taking the family to see Deadpool & Wolverine, in theaters now. (Warning: Some spoilers ahead.)\n\nThere is frequent bloody violence\n\nThroughout the movie, there are gory, over-the-top violence and action scenes, often played for laughs. (The opening action scene features Deadpool dancing along to *NSYNC while killing countless adversaries.)\n\nThere are guns, claws, swords galore. Mutant characters also use their powers to fight in bloody fashion.\n\nNonstop coarse language is used\n\nReynolds' Deadpool character isn't nicknamed the Merc with a Mouth for nothing. There is an onslaught of F-bombs from start to finish, plus every other vulgarity in between.\n\nDirector Levy joked to Variety, \"Ryan has a superpower of being able to invent forms of swearing that humankind has never known.\"\n\nThere are many sexual references\n\nAnother hallmark of the Deadpool brand of humor are irreverent sexual jokes. There are references to erections, sexual harassment, genitals and other sex acts. Parts of Wolverine's mask, for example, are referred to as \"blowjob handles\" at one point.\n\nProducer Kevin Feige, the president of Marvel Studios, told Variety he had to explain what \"pegging\" is to some people at the company because of a joke used in the movie.\n\n\"There's a line in the red-band trailer -- you don't have to write this in the article, for crying out loud -- about pegging,\" Feige told the outlet. \"I know what pegging is, it's in the first Deadpool movie. But there were people I work with who didn't know what it was. I had to explain it to them.\"\n\nThere are some mentions of drug use\n\nThere are several mentions of cocaine throughout the film, as Leslie Uggams' character Blind Al and Deadpool talk about the drug and give it code names. One of those pseudonyms, for example, is \"the Devil's dandruff.\"\n\nA joke in the movie suggests producer Feige forbid them from cocaine references in the film. He told Variety, \"We were open to anything. Maybe I'm slightly prudish when it comes to drug use, but I was like, 'Eh, it's not that funny.' \"", "source": {"uri": "people.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PEOPLE.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-433595660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:25:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:25:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:23:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.cinemablend.com/superheroes/marvel-cinematic-universe/deadpool-and-wolverine-story-flaws-critics-reaction-ryan-reynolds", "title": "'Laughing In Tears': Despite Deadpool And Wolverine's Story Flaws, Critics Say Ryan Reynolds' Jokes Are Ruthless As He Enters The MCU", "body": "When Deadpool & Wolverine hits theaters on July 26 as the latest of many upcoming Marvel movies, anyone who's seen Ryan Reynolds' first two offerings knows a little of what to expect. The snarky, fourth-wall-breaking superhero is back, this time with Hugh Jackman's Wolverine in a pairing that's seemed inevitable from the beginning. Many critics considered it the \"ultimate Deadpool movie\" following initial screenings, and that means that despite some flaws in the story, audiences can expect to laugh. In fact, those who have seen the movie say Reynolds' character comes so hard (heh) with the jokes that a second viewing is a necessity.\n\nMuch in the same way that Barbie took shots at Mattel in one of 2023's best movies, Ryan Reynolds apparently doesn't pull too many punches on the MCU in this one, so grab your wild Deadpool 3 popcorn bucket, and let's see what critics have to say, starting with CinemaBlend's review of Deadpool & Wolverine. Eric Eisenberg gives it 3.5 stars out of 5, noting the film's gratuitous fan service and complete mess of a narrative. However, it's still a \"raucous good time,\" made palatable with a healthy dose of self-awareness. He says:\n\nDavid Ehrlich of IndieWire gives it a C+ for thin plotting and other story issues, but agrees that fans will be won over by the humor and cameos, one of which left the critic crying with laughter in his screening. Ehrlich writes:\n\nPete Hammond of Deadline loves Deadpool & Wolverine's salty dialogue, and while Hugh Jackman is \"perfection\" as the clawed superhero, it's the glee Ryan Reynolds takes in bringing his character's crude humor and off-color jokes to the MCU that makes this movie so enjoyable. In the critic's words:\n\nTom Jorgensen of IGN rates it a \"Good\" 7 out of 10, and while this critic thinks Ryan Reynolds may have sanded off the edges of a few of his jokes, what his character does bring to the table breathes new, menacing life into the MCU. Jorgensen continues:\n\nJohn Kirk of Original Cin gives it an A, saying that fans ultimately aren't going to care that the story is weak, because the fights are massive and the jokes are flying nonstop. In Kirk's words:\n\nWhether you've seen all of the Marvel movies in order or just the first two Deadpool movies (which can be streamed with a Disney+ subscription), the critics seem to agree that Ryan Reynolds' irreverent superhero is back at full strength with his quips in Deadpool & Wolverine. Just be prepared to carve out another two hours in your schedule for a second viewing. {"uri": "8243332548", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:43:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:43:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:42:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/25/deadpool-wolverine-reviews-are-in-amusing-or-exhausting/", "title": "'Deadpool & Wolverine' Reviews Are In: Amusing or Exhausting?", "body": "After a summer without superheroes, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is slashing its way into theaters.\n\nThe high-octane collision of the wisecracking antihero Deadpool, played by Ryan Reynolds in two previous films, and the hulking and messianic Wolverine, played by Hugh Jackman (returning to the role for the first time since \"Logan\" in 2017), marks Marvel Studios' only release of the calendar year. The movie, directed by Shawn Levy, is projected to have the best ever domestic opening weekend for an R-rated film.\n\nMost critics have found something to like in \"Deadpool & Wolverine,\" which has an 81 percent fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes. They say it has a superpowered jokes-per-minute ratio and two winning performances from its lead actors. But many reviewers had a mixed-to-negative assessment of the movie overall, calling it difficult to follow, lacking in real tension or stakes and overly reliant on self-referential story lines.\n\nThe movie's aggressive sense of humor about itself may win you over despite its flaws. \"'Deadpool & Wolverine' isn't a particularly good movie -- I'm not even sure it is a movie,\" Bilge Ebiri wrote. \"But it's so determined to beat you down with its incessant irreverence that you might find yourself submitting to it.\"\n\nNothing Ever Ends [The New York Times]\n\nThe movie's existence reflects Hollywood's inability to \"let well enough alone,\" wrote Alissa Wilkinson, but it's entertaining nonetheless. \"It still features Reynolds making fun of himself; it has some fun set pieces, clever sight gags, amusing surprises, left-field references and adoring pauses to admire Jackman's biceps and abs.\"\n\n'Deadpool & Wolverine' Makes the M.C.U. the Villain -- and Not in a Good Way [Polygon]\n\nIn a negative review, Joshua Rivera found the film dispiritingly hollow. \"'Deadpool & Wolverine' has made its hero the worst kind of comic book character: one who doesn't stand for anything.\"\n\nRyan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman's Sarky Gagathon Mocks the M.C.U. Back to Life [The Guardian]\n\nPeter Bradshaw appreciated the movie's satirical bent while capturing a common complaint about it in a few words. \"It's amusing and exhausting,\" he wrote.\n\nThe Superhero Movie Finally Accepts Itself for What It Is [The Associated Press]\n\nIn a mixed review, Krysta Fauria said the film loses its way in the middle but ultimately sticks the landing. \"The bloody but comedic final fight scene, however, is enough to perk viewers back up for the last act, solidifying the film's identity as a fun, generally well-made summer movie.\"\n\nRyan Reynolds Blasts Into the M.C.U. with a Meta-Sequel That Nakedly Tries to Save Superhero Movies From Extinction [IndieWire]\n\nDavid Ehrlich found a kernel of tenderness beneath the lewd and crude action. \"'Deadpool & Wolverine' rescues something kind of beautiful from the ugliness that superhero movies have perpetuated for so long.\"\n\nRelentlessly Irritating, With Cheap Jokes Instead of Stake [Entertainment Weekly]\n\nThe film left a bad taste in the mouth of Jordan Hoffman, who found it \"simply too repetitive, too immature and too irritating to enjoy.\" \"It's unbelievable just how annoying it is,\" he wrote.\n\nRyan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman's R-Rated Bromance Is an Irreverent Send-Off to Fox's X-Men Movies [Variety]\n\nDeadpool's desire in the film to leave a meaningful legacy is a compelling microcosm of the challenge facing all superhero stories, which are \"at the mercy of both Marvel and the market,\" wrote Peter Debruge. \"In its own uniquely self-aware way, the movie confronts that phenomenon without overstaying its welcome.\"", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": friendship, which Reynolds said during an appearance on hot wing interview show \"Hot Ones\" this week is the foundation on which their new Marvel film is built.\n\n\"When we are together outside of our public persona taking the piss out of each other, most of our conversations are very vulnerable,\" Reynolds said in the clip, which was published to YouTube on Thursday.\n\nJackman, who sat next to Reynolds with tears in his eyes as he fought the heat of the hot wing he just ate, agreed and went on to describe his co-star as a \"great father, great family, great friend, loves his job, loves his work.\"\n\n\"It is a movie that is built on the foundation of friendship,\" Reynolds later added. \"It's a story about friendship.\"\n\nPerhaps that's why \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" may resonate so {"uri": "2024-07-433280908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:26:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:26:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:26:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.radiotimes.com/app/deadpool-wolverine-review-could-ryan-reynolds-crude-antihero-actually-be-marvels-messiah/", "title": "Deadpool & Wolverine review: Could Ryan Reynolds' crude antihero actually be Marvel's messiah?", "body": "To say there is a lot riding on Deadpool & Wolverine, the third Deadpool adventure, both critically and financially, may seem like an odd assertion, considering both of his previous escapades made a healthy $780 million at the worldwide box office and went down well with audiences, critics and fans alike.\n\nBut much has changed since Deadpool 2 was released in 2018, with Disney completing its acquisition of 21st Century Fox a year later and having the lucrative opportunity to add that studio's X-Men characters, Deadpool included, to the Marvel Cinematic Universe. However, the MCU's fortunes have faltered since 2019 and the $2 billion heyday of Avengers: Endgame. Audiences and takings are down, with last year's The Marvels barely making $200 million and already announced titles delayed by years.\n\nDeadpool & Wolverine is the only MCU film out this year, so the notion that Ryan Reynolds's lewd, rude Merc with a Mouth will be Disney-Marvel's saviour is not a ludicrous one. Indeed, Reynolds spells it out with typical fourth-wall-smashing gusto from the start, when he declares himself the \"Marvel Jesus\" after being enlisted to help the Time Variance Authority with their multiversal problems.\n\nFollowers of the Loki TV series will already know about the TVA and its mission to protect the Multiverse by trimming failing alternate realities. But when Wade Wilson (aka Deadpool) realises TVA agent Mr Paradox (played by Succession star Matthew Macfadyen) is threatening the lives of his friends and his lover (Morena Baccarin), he decides he will need muscular assistance from iconic X-Man the Wolverine (a welcome return for Hugh Jackman). But, hold on. Wasn't Logan in 2017 the final chapter for Jackman's ageing mutant mauler? Well, yes and no, as we see from the bloody, all-action opening when Wade revisits Logan's final resting place in the hope his healing factor might have kicked in. Let's just say Wade must look elsewhere in the multiverse, so we get the chance to check out a range of Wolverine variants that will be familiar to many a longtime comic book fan.\n\nEventually, it's a bitter, booze-guzzling Logan -- \"the worst Wolverine\" -- who is persuaded to help, and then this very funny, action-packed romp hurtles into its own as the pair bicker and battle with each other and nearly everyone else they meet after they are dumped into The Void, an inter-dimensional dumping ground ruled over by psychic psycho Cassandra Nova (The Crown's Emma Corrin).\n\nHere, the self-aware send-ups come thick and fast - the duo fight in the rubble of the 20th Century Fox logo - as do some genuinely gob-smacking cameos and callbacks to Marvel's cinematic history. The wanton slice-and-dice violence, expletives on tap and throwaway gibes at the likes of Marvel chief Kevin Feige and Mad Max film Furiosa quell any concerns Deadpool may get Disneyfied.\n\nAdmittedly, the in-jokes and quickfire banter may not travel so well for the uninitiated punter, but like Airplane!, there is enough pithy patter and gags (deftly delivered by director Shawn Levy) to leave you smiling or laughing out loud. Reynolds, meanwhile, is at his impish best, and he has the perfect foil in a suitably gruff Jackman, who provides timely gravitas among all the mirth and mayhem.\n\nTime (and billion-dollar box office targets) will tell if Deadpool is indeed the saviour of the MCU and can get lots of bums onto lots of seats. Or will this third outing be just a fillip before the release of Captain America: Brave New World in February 2025, which will see Anthony Mackie take on the mantle of the star-spangled Avenger? Roll on next year.", "source": {"uri": "radiotimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Radio Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jeremy_aspinall@radiotimes.com", "name": "Jeremy Aspinall", "type": "author", {"uri": "8243625461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:56:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:56:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:55:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://celebrity.nine.com.au/latest/blake-lively-deadpool-and-wolverine/0e55308e-b644-4f3b-9865-7e929e274c42", "title": "One line buried in movie credits exposed Blake Lively's secret role", "body": "Blake Lively's secret role in Ryan Reynold's new movie Deadpool & Wolverine exposed\n\nMarvel fans, be warned; this article is chock full of spoilers for Deadpool & Wolverine, including the identity of Lady Deadpool, so click away if you're not ready.\n\nFor those who remain, the mystery of which famous face was under Lady Deadpool's mask in the new movie has finally been solved - and it's exactly who many fans expected.\n\nIt's been confirmed in both the credits that play at the end of the film and on IMDb, where's she's listed near the bottom of the cast list.\n\nAnd it turns out she wasn't the only member of the Lively-Reynolds family to make a cameo in Deadpool & Wolverine.\n\nFor a daily dose of 9honey, subscribe to our newsletter here.\n\nEagle-eyed viewers noticed another familiar name as the credits rolled: Inez Reynolds.\n\nLively and Ryan's seven-year-old daughter made a tiny cameo as the character 'Kidpool' (kid Deadpool) and her short lines included some serious language for a kid who hasn't even hit double digits.\n\nShe's the second of their four daughters, along with James, nine, and Betty, four, and Olin, who is only a few months old.\n\nREAD MORE: Why Ryan Reynolds' daughter threatened to 'divorce' him\n\nWhile no-one expected Inez to make an appearance in her dad's new movie with Australian acting icon Hugh Jackman, most fans weren't surprised to learn Lively was involved.\n\nFrom the very first moment Lady Deadpool appeared in a trailer for the new flick, there was speculation about who could be hiding {"uri": "8243401943", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:39:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:39:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:33:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/entertainment/2803347/", "title": "Kevin Feige Talks Who Will Next Play Wolverine in the MCU - ExBulletin", "body": "With Deadpool and Wolverine hitting theaters this weekend, the question is what happens to each character next, but especially Wolverine in the promised next mutant era of the MCU.\n\nWhile there are rumors of Jackman's return, will he return for good? That's a more open question, and one that Kevin Feige is asking. was asked by Discussing Film about the possibility of Wolverine one day getting a new actor. Here's what he said:\n\nYeah. You know, Marvel is celebrating its 85th anniversary later this summer. That's just the first 85 years, and Disney just celebrated its 100th anniversary as well. I think these characters will be around for another 100 years, long after all of us. So, for sure, there will be [eventually another actor as Wolverine]. I think it will be in a very different style and in a different way. I also think if someone tried to do an imitation of Hugh Jackman as Wolverine, that would be a big mistake.\n\nHe then has a follow-up quote saying essentially the same thing, although there is no immediate plans to replace Jackman:\n\nAs comic book readers know, there have been various and very different versions of these characters over the decades. It would be fun to explore more of them someday. Again, we don't have immediate plans by all means. But in the coming decades, I think it is inevitable. If it happens, it will have to be a very different and bold reinterpretation of [the character] because no one will be as good as Hugh Jackman at doing his own version of Wolverine.\n\n< position=\"inread\" progressive=\"\" ad-id=\"article-0-inread\" aria-hidden=\"true\" role=\"presentation\"/>\n\nA lot of things are open to interpretation here. When you're talking about the character still being around 100 years from now, sure, it makes sense that you'd factor in people who aren't Hugh Jackman. But I don't think that necessarily means Jackman couldn't play Wolverine in other X-Men movies for another five years or so?\n\nThe second quote also makes me think about this sentence: As comic book readers know, there have been various and very, very different versions of these characters over the decades. It would be fun to explore more of them someday.\n\nWhen it comes to Wolverine, the most different take on the character is Laura Kinney, X-23, taking over the role of Wolverine from the comics, something the Marvel Universe has already set up with Logan and now Dafne Keens' take on Laura in Deadpool and Wolverine. I've said before that she's the only actress who makes sense to take over the role in the near future, and I wonder if Feige is hinting at that.\n\nI'd be shocked if we didn't get Jackman's Wolverine in the next Avengers movies or early in the future X-Men movies. {"uri": "2024-07-433799264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:22:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:22:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:15:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.com/deadpool-and-wolverine-end-credits-scene-explained-2024-7", "title": "'Deadpool & Wolverine' has one end-credits scene  --  here's what happens", "body": "This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? Log in.\n\nAfter the movie ends, fans are treated to archival footage from past Marvel films before an end credits scene. Here's what you need to know.\n\nThe credits roll alongside behind-the-scenes footage from the 'X-Men' movies and other past Marvel films\n\nJackman has played Wolverine since the 2000 ensemble movie \"X-Men.\" He reprised the role for additional \"X-Men\" sequels and the stand-alone Wolverine franchise. Although the character sacrificed himself in the 2017 movie \"Logan,\" Jackman returns as a Wolverine variant in \"Deadpool & Wolverine.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Reynolds made his debut as Wade Wilson in \"X-Men Origins: Wolverine\" in 2009. Years later, he overhauled the character and gave the Merc with a Mouth new life in a wildly successful \"Deadpool\" franchise.\n\nThe footage shown to the right of the credits pays homage to their lengthy Marvel careers, to the tune of Green Day's \"Good Riddance (Time of Your Life).\"\n\nThe montage includes footage of Jackman on the set of the \"X-Men\" movies with Patrick Stewart (Charles Xavier/Professor X), Halle Berry (Storm), and his other costars. It also features footage of Chris Evans on the set of the original \"Fantastic Four\" films and snippets of scenes from the \"Fantastic Four\" reboot, \"X-Men: Apocalypse,\" \"X-Men: Dark Phoenix,\" and other Marvel movies.\n\nIt concludes with the 20th Century Fox logo, in yet another meta jab at the 2019 Disney/Fox merger.\n\nThe end-credits scene gives Chris Evans even more screen time as Johnny Storm\n\nIn \"Deadpool & Wolverine,\" Chris Evans reprises his role as the lovable-yet-cocky Johnny Storm/Human Torch. Although the actor is primarily associated with his part as Steve Rogers/Captain America in the MCU, he previously played Johnny in \"Fantastic Four\" (2005) and \"Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer\" (2007).\n\nDeadpool and Wolverine encounter Johnny in a wasteland called The Void. Then they're captured and taken to the lair of villain Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrin).\n\nWhile in the convoy together, Johnny explains that The Void is a metaphysical junkyard where people are sent by the Time Variance Authority (TVA) before being annihilated by an entity known as Alioth. He says that people who end up here are either eaten by Alioth or work for Cassandra.\n\nWhen Deadpool meets Cassandra, he repeats all the rude comments that Johnny made about her in the convoy verbatim. Johnny denies speaking out against Cassandra, but she viciously kills him anyway by ripping the skin from his body telepathically leaving behind his skeleton and a puddle of blood.\n\nMarvel end-credits scenes often tease what's to come in future projects. Other times, they're tongue-in-cheek scenes that are inconsequential.\n\nThe \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" end-credits scene milks Evans' cameo for everything it's worth by elaborating on the moment that led to Johnny's brutal death.\n\nIn the scene, Wade stands inside the TVA room alone and breaks the fourth wall, telling the audience that he's tired of the rumors that he got Johnny killed. To prove that he wasn't lying about everything Johnny said, Deadpool plays back footage from the convoy on one of the TVA's retro TVs. The footage clearly shows Johnny going on a crude, expletive-filled rant about why he despises Cassandra.\n\nIt's unclear where in the MCU Deadpool will show up next, but he's clearly satisfied with the way this film ends.\n\n\"Gotcha, fuckface,\" Deadpool says before walking away.", "source": {"uri": "businessinsider.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Business Insider"}, "authors": [{"uri": On the convention's preview night, scores of fans were sporting clothing or costumes featuring the movie's characters.\n\nRyan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, who play the titular superheroes, will join director Shawn Levy in the San Diego Convention Center's famed Hall H Thursday. To prevent fans from camping out in lines all day to snag a seat, organizers created a lottery system for the chance to win tickets. The venue holds about 6,000 people.\n\nSome fans, conditioned to expect surprise guests and never-before-seen footage from years of experience at the convention, are speculating the panel will be followed by a screening of the film, which hits theaters Friday.\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine\" marks the debut of Reynolds and Jackman's characters in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Disney and the Marvel Cinematic Universe are the subject of several jokes throughout the trailer. Both Deadpool and Wolverine's characters existed in films previously under the 21st Century Fox banner.\n\nThe release comes at a time of increasing conversations about a general \"superhero fatigue,\" with audiences showing less enthusiasm for superhero movies both within the MCU and beyond. Part of that fatigue comes from a feeling that to understand a superhero movie today requires background research into the lore of the characters and comics, with much required viewing and reading.\n\nLevy said in an April interview with The Associated Press that he wanted to make sure his movie didn't require that intense level of preparation.\n\n\"I was a good student in school. I'll do my homework as an adult. But I am definitely not looking to do homework when I go to the movies,\" Levy said.\n\n\"I very much made this film with certainly a healthy respect and gratitude towards the rabid fan base that has peak fluency in the mythology and lore of these characters and this world. But I didn't want to presume that. This movie is built for entertainment, with no obligation to come prepared with prior research.\"\n\nAlthough Marvel is anxious for a hit following box-office underperformance in of \"The Marvels\" and \"Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania\" in 2023, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is tracking to open in the $160 million range. That would unseat \"Inside Out 2\" for the biggest opening of the year -- and quash any discussion of superhero fatigue.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, It's sort of audacious because it's a real tricky thing to get right,\" said MacFadyen. \"And I think they do get it right.\"\n\n\"At its heart, I think it's kind of about these unlikely friends in a story of friendship which I don't think you've seen so much in the 'Deadpool' universe,\" said Corrin. \"I've never laughed so much in my life but I was also sincerely moved.\"\n\nRob Delaney is back for more fun. After first appearing as a character not in the comics in \"Deadpool 2.\" Flash forward to what you'll see in this movie...and Delaney doesn't mince words.\n\n\"It is so legitimately insane, the things in the movie, but none of it is just, like, 'We got to make sure we get that R.' {"uri": "2024-07-433307117", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:49:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:49:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:49:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.radiotimes.com/movies/scifi/deadpool-wolverine-post-credits-scene-explained/", "title": "Does Deadpool & Wolverine have a post-credits scene?", "body": "The post-credits scene has become one of Marvel's biggest trademarks over the years, with numerous closing stings having been included to set up major new plot developments or to provide one final gag for the audience.\n\nIn the past, the Deadpool movies have opted for the latter approach, which is of course very much in keeping with the character's wise-cracking reputation.\n\nThe first film poked fun at audiences for sticking around so long just to be met with something so anti-climactic while the second entry made a memorable meta joke about Ryan Reynolds's previous less-than-successful superhero appearance in the much-maligned 2011 film Green Lantern.\n\nBut with the character now having officially joined the MCU in the newly released Deadpool & Wolverine, what has been saved for the end this time around? Is it another throw-away gag, or could it perhaps be something hinting at bigger things to come for the character now he's been fully folded into the franchise?\n\nRead on for everything you need to know about the Deadpool & Wolverine post-credits scene.\n\nDoes Deadpool & Wolverine have a post-credits scene?\n\nYes! During the credits themselves, we are shown a montage scored by classic Green Day hit Good Riddance (Time of Your Life) which consists of behind-the-scenes footage from previous X-Men and other Fox Marvel films - with younger Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds both appearing. It's a huge treat for fans of the films.\n\nAnd after that, there is indeed one final post-credits scene, which very much falls into the joke category rather than anything more substantial.\n\nIt's a call-back to an earlier moment in the film, with Deadpool desperate to clear his name after being accused of putting words in Johnny Storm's (Chris Evans) mouth which had led to his brutal death at the hands of Cassandra Nova.\n\nIn that scene, Deadpool had accused Johnny of saying all sorts of extremely vulgar and foul-mouthed things about the villain, which Johnny fruitlessly protested had been completely fabricated. In the aftermath, Deadpool had faced plenty of flak from Logan for supposedly making this up and directly causing Johnny's death.\n\nWell, the post-credits sting sees Deadpool return to the TVA to review the footage and prove he'd actually not made up a thing: Johnny had uttered every single insult he'd been accused of, word-for-word. And with no shortage of gusto!\n\nSo while this doesn't exactly bring Johnny back from his violent demise, at the very least it shows that Deadpool hadn't been dishonest about his remarks. {"uri": "2024-07-433741643", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:45:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:45:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:14:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.clickondetroit.com/entertainment/2024/07/25/deadpool-wolverine-dominates-at-comic-con-ahead-of-panel-with-ryan-reynolds-hugh-jackman/", "title": "'Deadpool & Wolverine' dominates at Comic-Con ahead of panel with Ryan Reynolds, Hugh Jackman", "body": "SAN DIEGO - \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" has arrived -- and Comic-Con, with its hordes of Marvel fans, is ready to celebrate the only superhero flick of the summer.\n\nThe sprawling convention celebrating all things pop culture kicked off Wednesday, and a panel celebrating the release of \"Deadpool & Wolverine,\" is the main attraction for Thursday. On the convention's preview night, scores of fans were sporting clothing or costumes featuring the movie's characters.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nRyan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, who play the titular superheroes, will join director Shawn Levy in the San Diego Convention Center's famed Hall H Thursday. To prevent fans from camping out in lines all day to snag a seat, organizers created a lottery system for the chance to win tickets. The venue holds about 6,000 people.\n\nSome fans, conditioned to expect surprise guests and never-before-seen footage from years of experience at the convention, are speculating the panel will be followed by a screening of the film, which hits theaters Friday.\n\n\"Deadpool & Wolverine\" marks the debut of Reynolds and Jackman's characters in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Disney and the Marvel Cinematic Universe are the subject of several jokes throughout the trailer. Both Deadpool and Wolverine's characters existed in films previously under the 21st Century Fox banner.\n\nThe release comes at a time of increasing conversations about a general \"superhero fatigue,\" with audiences showing less enthusiasm for superhero movies both within the MCU and beyond. Part of that fatigue comes from a feeling that to understand a superhero movie today requires background research into the lore of the characters and comics, with much required viewing and reading.\n\nLevy said in an April interview with The Associated Press that he wanted to make sure his movie didn't require that intense level of preparation.\n\n\"I was a good student in school. I'll do my homework as an adult. But I am definitely not looking to do homework when I go to the movies,\" Levy said.\n\n\"I very much made this film with certainly a healthy respect and gratitude towards the rabid fan base that has peak fluency in the mythology and lore of these characters and this world. But I didn't want to presume that. This movie is built for entertainment, with no obligation to come prepared with prior research.\"\n\nAlthough Marvel is anxious for a hit following box-office underperformance in of \"The Marvels\" and \"Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania\" in 2023, \"Deadpool & Wolverine\" is tracking to open in the $160 million range. That would unseat \"Inside Out 2\" for the biggest opening of the year -- and quash any discussion of superhero fatigue.\n\nWith generally positive reviews, rousing enthusiasm at Comic-Con and an endorsement from Taylor Swift where she called the film a \"joy portal,\" Marvel's latest movie is set to be a box-office hit.", "source": {"uri": "clickondetroit.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
